name: Idli
steps: Wash and soak idli rice and urad dal separately for 6 hours.
Soak fenugreek seeds along with urad dal.
Drain water and grind urad dal + fenugreek into a fluffy batter.
Grind rice separately into a coarse batter.
Mix both batters in a large bowl.
Add water gradually to get a thick pouring consistency.
Cover the bowl and keep it in a warm place for 8-12 hours to ferment.
Check after fermentation, batter should rise and turn airy.
Add salt and mix gently without overbeating.
Grease idli moulds with oil.
Pour batter into moulds up to 3/4th level.
Heat water in idli steamer.
Place the filled idli stand inside steamer.
Steam for 10-12 minutes on medium flame.
Check if done by inserting a toothpick, it should come out clean.
Remove stand and let idlis cool for 2 minutes.
Scoop out idlis using a wet spoon.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney and Udupi sambar.

name: Moode (Kotte Kadubu)
ingredients: Banana leaves or screw pine leaves (for moulds)
steps: Wash and soak rice and dal separately for 6 hours.
Soak fenugreek seeds with urad dal.
Grind urad dal and fenugreek seeds to a fluffy batter.
Grind rice coarsely.
Mix both batters, add water as needed.
Allow batter to ferment overnight or 8-10 hours.
Once fermented, add salt and mix gently.
Clean and cut banana leaves or screw pine leaves into rectangular sheets.
Fold them into cylindrical cones and secure with thread.
Grease the insides of these cones lightly.
Pour fermented batter into leaf moulds up to 3/4th level.
Arrange moulds vertically in a steamer.
Steam for 20-25 minutes.
Check doneness using a knife tip.
Cool for 2-3 minutes before peeling the leaves.
Unwrap to reveal soft cylindrical kadubu.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, saaru, or honey.

name: Pundi (Rice Dumplings)
steps: Wash and soak rice for 4 hours.
Drain water and grind rice into coarse batter (not too fine).
Heat coconut oil in a pan.
Add mustard seeds, let them splutter.
Add urad dal and fry till golden.
Add curry leaves and grated coconut, sauté lightly.
Pour in 4 cups of water and bring to boil.
Add salt as per taste.
Gradually add the ground rice batter into boiling water.
Stir continuously to avoid lumps.
Cook till mixture thickens and leaves sides of pan.
Cool slightly, grease hands with oil.
Shape mixture into small lemon-sized balls.
Arrange dumplings in greased idli plates.
Steam cook for 12-15 minutes.
Check doneness with a knife tip.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney or spicy red chutney.

name: Sanna (Mangalore Steamed Rice Cakes)
steps: Soak rice and urad dal separately for 6 hours.
Grind urad dal to a fluffy batter.
Grind rice with grated coconut to a fine paste.
Mix both batters in a large bowl.
Dissolve yeast in warm water with sugar.
Add yeast mixture to batter and mix well.
Allow to ferment for 8 hours or overnight.
After fermentation, batter should rise well.
Add salt and mix gently.
Grease small steel bowls or moulds.
Pour batter up to 3/4th level.
Place bowls in a steamer.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Cool for 2 minutes before unmoulding.
Remove sannas carefully with a spoon.
howToServe: Serve warm with chicken curry, kori gassi, or chutney.

name: Pathrode
steps: Soak rice for 4 hours.
Grind rice with red chilies, coconut, tamarind, jaggery, and turmeric into a thick paste.
Wash colocasia leaves and pat dry.
Remove thick veins with a knife.
Place one leaf upside down and spread batter evenly.
Place another leaf on top, repeat spreading batter.
Stack 6-8 leaves this way.
Roll tightly from one end to another into a cylinder.
Secure roll with thread if required.
Place in steamer and steam for 25-30 minutes.
Check doneness with a knife tip.
Remove roll and allow to cool for 5 minutes.
Cut into 1-inch thick slices.
Optional: shallow fry slices in oil till crispy.
Serve directly or with coconut oil drizzle.
howToServe: Serve warm as snack or side dish with coconut chutney or jaggery syrup.

name: Mudde Idli (Ragi Idli)
steps: Wash and soak urad dal with fenugreek seeds for 6 hours.
Grind urad dal into a fluffy batter.
Mix ragi flour with water to form a smooth paste.
Add idli rava to the ragi mixture and mix well.
Combine urad dal batter with the ragi-rava mixture.
Adjust consistency by adding water if too thick.
Ferment overnight or 8-10 hours.
After fermentation, add salt and mix gently.
Grease idli plates with oil.
Pour batter into moulds up to 3/4th level.
Heat water in steamer.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Check doneness with a toothpick.
Let cool for 2 minutes before removing.
Scoop out idlis with a wet spoon.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney and spicy onion chutney.

name: Thatte Idli (Plate Idli)
steps: Wash and soak rice and dal separately for 6 hours.
Soak fenugreek seeds along with dal.
Grind urad dal into a smooth fluffy batter.
Grind rice into a slightly coarse batter.
Mix both batters in a large bowl.
Add water gradually to adjust consistency.
Ferment overnight or 8-12 hours.
After fermentation, add salt and mix gently.
Grease wide plates (thatte) with oil.
Pour batter into plates to 1/2 inch thickness.
Place plates inside steamer.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool slightly before cutting pieces.
Lift idli carefully from the plate.
howToServe: Serve hot with chutney pudi and ghee or coconut chutney.

name: Khotto (Jackfruit Leaf Idli)
steps: Soak rice and urad dal separately for 6 hours.
Grind urad dal with fenugreek seeds to a fluffy batter.
Grind rice coarsely and mix with dal batter.
Adjust consistency with water.
Ferment for 8-10 hours.
After fermentation, add salt and mix gently.
Wash and dry jackfruit leaves.
Make square cups by pinning 4 leaves together with toothpicks.
Grease inside of leaf cups with oil.
Pour batter into the cups up to 3/4th level.
Arrange cups vertically inside steamer.
Steam for 20-25 minutes.
Check doneness by inserting a knife tip.
Let cool slightly before removing.
Peel leaves away to reveal steamed khotto.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut oil, chutney, or sambar.

name: Nuchchinunde (Steamed Dal Dumplings)
steps: Wash and soak toor dal and chana dal for 3 hours.
Drain and grind coarsely with green chilies and ginger.
Do not add excess water.
Transfer to a bowl and add salt, grated coconut, coriander.
Mix gently to form a thick coarse mixture.
Grease hands with oil.
Shape mixture into oval dumplings.
Grease idli plates or steaming plates.
Place dumplings carefully without overcrowding.
Heat water in steamer.
Steam dumplings for 15 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool for 2 minutes.
Remove dumplings carefully.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney or majjige huli.

name: Sweet Kadubu (Steamed Stuffed Dumpling)
steps: Heat a pan, add grated coconut and jaggery.
Cook till jaggery melts and blends with coconut.
Add cardamom powder, mix well.
Cool mixture and set aside.
Boil 1.5 cups of water with a pinch of salt.
Add rice flour gradually, stirring continuously.
Cook till mixture forms a soft dough.
Cover and rest dough for 5 minutes.
Grease hands with ghee.
Pinch small balls from dough and flatten into discs.
Place 1 tbsp coconut-jaggery filling inside.
Fold and seal edges to form semicircle.
Wrap dumplings in banana leaves.
Arrange in a steamer.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Cool slightly before serving.
howToServe: Serve warm with a drizzle of ghee during festivals.

name: Kai Kadubu (Coconut Stuffed Kadubu)
steps: Heat a pan and add grated coconut with jaggery.
Cook till jaggery melts and blends with coconut.
Add cardamom powder, mix well and set aside.
Boil 1.5 cups water with a pinch of salt.
Gradually add rice flour, stirring continuously.
Mix till it forms a soft dough.
Cover and rest the dough for 5 minutes.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take a small portion of dough and roll into discs.
Place coconut-jaggery mixture inside.
Fold into semicircles and seal edges.
Wrap dumplings in banana leaves.
Arrange them in a steamer.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Cool slightly before serving.
howToServe: Serve warm with ghee during festive occasions.

name: Hitikida Avarekalu Kadubu
steps: Wash and peel avarekalu beans.
Cook beans in water till soft and mash lightly.
Mix grated coconut, jaggery, and cardamom with cooked beans.
Boil 2 cups water and add rice flour gradually.
Cook till dough consistency is achieved.
Cool slightly and knead into soft dough.
Grease hands with oil and take small portions.
Flatten dough into discs.
Stuff each disc with avarekalu mixture.
Fold into kadubu shape and seal edges.
Place kadubus in banana leaves or greased idli plates.
Steam for 15 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool slightly before serving.
Remove and serve warm.
howToServe: Serve warm with ghee or as part of festival meal.

name: Southekayi Kadubu (Cucumber Idli)
steps: Wash and grate cucumber with skin.
Mix grated cucumber with rice rava.
Add grated coconut, chopped green chilies, and coriander.
Mix well without adding extra water (cucumber releases water).
Add salt and mix thoroughly.
Let mixture rest for 15 minutes.
Grease idli moulds or banana leaves.
Spoon the cucumber batter into moulds.
Tap moulds to level batter.
Heat water in steamer.
Steam for 15-18 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool for 2-3 minutes.
Remove kadubu from moulds.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney or jaggery syrup.

name: Akki Kadubu (Rice Flour Dumpling)
steps: Boil 3 cups of water with salt.
Add rice flour gradually while stirring.
Cook till mixture forms dough consistency.
Cool slightly and knead into soft dough.
Add grated coconut, sesame seeds, cumin seeds to dough.
Knead again to incorporate.
Grease hands with oil.
Divide dough into small balls.
Flatten each into thick discs.
Grease idli plates with oil.
Arrange discs on idli plates.
Heat water in steamer.
Steam cook for 15 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool slightly before removing.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney or vegetable saaru.

name: Halasina Hannu Kadubu (Jackfruit Kadubu)
steps: Deseed ripe jackfruit and grind pulp smoothly.
Mix pulp with rice flour to form a thick batter.
Add grated coconut, jaggery, and cardamom powder.
Mix well into a smooth dough-like consistency.
Cut banana leaves into small squares.
Grease leaves lightly with oil.
Spread jackfruit mixture onto leaves.
Fold leaves into pockets or cones.
Arrange them in a steamer.
Steam for 20 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool slightly before peeling leaves.
Remove kadubu carefully.
Serve warm or at room temperature.
Optional: drizzle with ghee.
howToServe: Serve warm with ghee during monsoon or jackfruit season.

name: Kanchipuram Idli
steps: Wash and soak idli rice and urad dal along with fenugreek seeds separately for 4–6 hours.
Grind urad dal with water until fluffy and smooth.
Grind rice coarsely, not too smooth, to maintain texture.
Mix both batters together with salt and allow to ferment overnight or at least 8 hours.
Once fermented, add thick curd to the batter and mix gently.
Heat ghee and sesame oil in a small pan.
Add cumin seeds, coarsely crushed pepper, chopped ginger, and green chilies.
Add curry leaves and a pinch of hing, sauté lightly until fragrant.
Cool this tempering and mix into the fermented batter.
Grease idli plates or a flat-steamed dish with oil or ghee.
Pour the prepared batter into the plates or flat dish, filling them about 3/4 full.
Steam the batter for 15–20 minutes until cooked through.
Check doneness by inserting a skewer or toothpick; it should come out clean.
Allow it to cool slightly before demolding.
Cut into slices if steamed in a flat dish, or remove whole idlis from molds.
Serve hot with chutney, sambar, or molagapodi.
howToServe: Serve Kanchipuram Idlis hot, garnished with a drizzle of ghee, alongside coconut chutney, tomato chutney, or sambar. They can also be enjoyed with podi mixed in oil for an authentic traditional taste.

name: Menthya Kadubu (Fenugreek Kadubu)
steps: Soak rice, urad dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 6 hours.
Grind urad dal into fluffy batter.
Grind rice coarsely with coconut and turmeric.
Mix both batters together.
Ferment for 8-10 hours overnight.
After fermentation, add salt and mix gently.
Wash and cut banana leaves into squares.
Grease leaves with little oil.
Spoon batter onto leaves and fold them.
Arrange leaf packets in steamer.
Steam for 15-20 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool slightly before peeling leaves.
Remove kadubu carefully.
Serve fresh while warm.
howToServe: Serve with coconut chutney, saaru, or drizzle of ghee.

name: Tuppa Idli (Ghee Idli)
steps: Wash and soak rice and dal separately for 6 hours.
Soak fenugreek seeds with dal.
Grind urad dal with fenugreek into smooth batter.
Grind rice separately to coarse batter.
Mix both batters and ferment overnight.
Add salt after fermentation.
Grease idli moulds with oil.
Pour 2-3 drops of ghee into each mould.
Add ladleful of batter into moulds.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Check doneness with toothpick.
Let idlis rest for 2 minutes.
Scoop out idlis gently.
Optional: brush with melted ghee after steaming.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with chutney pudi and coconut chutney.

name: Jackfruit Seed Idli (Halasina Bijada Idli)
ingredients: 1/2 cup boiled jackfruit seeds (peeled and mashed)
steps: Soak rice and urad dal separately for 6 hours.
Grind urad dal with fenugreek into fluffy batter.
Grind rice into coarse paste.
Mix both batters with mashed jackfruit seeds.
Ferment overnight or 8 hours.
Add salt and stir gently.
Grease idli plates with oil.
Pour batter into moulds.
Steam for 12-15 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool slightly before unmoulding.
Lift idlis with spoon.
Idlis will have nutty flavor from jackfruit seeds.
Serve fresh.
Optional: add grated coconut to batter.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney or red chili chutney.

name: Banana Kadubu (Steamed Banana Dumpling)
steps: Mash ripe bananas smoothly.
Mix with jaggery, coconut, and cardamom.
Add rice flour gradually to make soft dough.
Adjust with little water if needed.
Cut banana leaves into squares.
Grease leaves lightly with oil.
Spread banana mixture onto leaves.
Fold leaves into half and seal edges.
Arrange leaf packets in steamer.
Steam for 15 minutes.
Check doneness with knife tip.
Cool for 2 minutes before peeling leaves.
Remove kadubu carefully.
Serve warm or at room temperature.
Optional: drizzle with ghee before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot as breakfast or evening snack during festivals.

name: Masala Dosa
ingredients: For masala filling: 4 boiled potatoes, 2 onions (sliced), 2 green chilies, 1 tsp mustard seeds, curry leaves, 1/2 tsp turmeric, salt, 2 tbsp oil
steps: Wash and soak rice, urad dal, and methi seeds separately for 6 hours.
Grind to a smooth batter and ferment overnight.
Boil potatoes, peel, and mash.
Heat oil, add mustard, curry leaves, green chilies, and onions.
Fry till golden, add turmeric and mashed potatoes.
Add salt, mix well, and keep filling aside.
Heat dosa tawa and pour a ladle of batter.
Spread into a thin dosa.
Drizzle oil or ghee around the edges.
Cook till golden brown and crisp.
Place potato filling in the center.
Fold dosa and remove.
Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.
howToServe: Serve crisp masala dosa with coconut chutney and piping hot sambar.

name: Neer Dosa
steps: Wash and soak rice for 5–6 hours.
Grind with water to make a very thin watery batter.
Add salt and mix well.
Heat dosa tawa and grease lightly.
Pour batter quickly in circular motion.
Tilt pan to spread batter evenly.
Cover and cook for 1 minute.
Remove without flipping.
Repeat for remaining batter.
howToServe: Serve soft neer dosa with coconut chutney, chicken curry, or veg sagu.

name: Set Dosa
steps: Soak rice, urad dal, and poha for 5 hours.
Grind to smooth batter and ferment overnight.
Heat dosa tawa and grease with oil.
Pour thick batter and spread small round dosa.
Drizzle oil on edges.
Cook until golden on one side.
Do not flip (optional).
Prepare 2–3 dosas together for a ‘set’.
howToServe: Serve fluffy set dosas with vegetable sagu and coconut chutney.

name: Ragi Dosa
steps: Soak urad dal for 4–5 hours and grind to smooth paste.
Mix with ragi flour and rice flour.
Add salt and water to make batter.
Ferment overnight.
Heat dosa tawa and pour a ladle of batter.
Spread like regular dosa.
Drizzle oil on sides.
Cook till crisp and golden.
Flip and cook briefly.
howToServe: Serve healthy ragi dosa with coconut chutney and vegetable kurma.

name: Paper Dosa
steps: Soak rice, urad dal, and methi seeds separately for 6 hours.
Grind smooth and ferment overnight.
Heat dosa tawa until very hot.
Pour batter and spread very thin.
Drizzle oil or ghee generously.
Cook until golden and crisp.
Do not flip.
Fold into long thin roll.
howToServe: Serve crispy paper dosa with chutney, sambar, or potato masala.

name: Uppu Huli Dosa
steps: Wash and soak rice for 3–4 hours.
Drain the water and grind soaked rice with grated coconut, red chilies, tamarind pulp, and jaggery.
Add water gradually while grinding to get a smooth batter.
Transfer batter to a bowl and mix salt as needed.
Heat a pan and add 1 tsp oil.
Crackle mustard seeds and curry leaves in hot oil, then mix this tempering into the batter.
Heat dosa tawa on medium flame and lightly grease with oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter in the center.
Spread slightly into a thick circle (not too thin).
Cover with a lid and cook on medium flame.
Drizzle little oil around edges if required.
Flip once and cook the other side for a minute.
Check for golden brown spots on both sides.
Remove from tawa and place on serving plate.
Repeat the process for remaining batter.
Serve hot with coconut chutney or jaggery syrup.
howToServe: Serve Uppu Huli Dosa hot with fresh coconut chutney, butter, or jaggery syrup. Best enjoyed for breakfast or evening snack.

name: Banana Dosa
steps: Peel and mash the ripe bananas into a smooth paste.
In a mixing bowl, add rice flour, jaggery, and grated coconut.
Mix in the mashed bananas and combine well.
Add cardamom powder and a pinch of salt for flavor.
Slowly add water and whisk to form a smooth, thick batter.
Let the batter rest for about 20–30 minutes for flavors to blend.
Heat a dosa tawa or skillet on medium heat.
Grease lightly with ghee or oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread gently into a small dosa (not too thin).
Cook on medium flame until bubbles appear on top.
Drizzle some ghee around the edges.
Flip carefully and cook the other side until golden brown.
Repeat for the remaining batter.
Adjust thickness of batter if needed by adding little water.
Serve hot when dosa is crisp on the edges and soft inside.
howToServe: Serve Banana Dosa hot with coconut chutney, honey, or jaggery syrup for a traditional Mangalorean touch.

name: Pundi Dosa
steps: Wash and soak rice for 4–5 hours.
Grind into a coarse batter with coconut and little water.
Add salt and mix well.
Keep batter slightly thick.
Heat dosa tawa on medium flame.
Pour a ladle of batter and spread into a thick dosa.
Drizzle little oil around edges.
Cover and cook till bottom turns golden.
Flip carefully and cook other side.
Ensure dosa is slightly crispy outside and soft inside.
Repeat for remaining batter.
If batter is too thick, sprinkle little water.
Adjust flame for even cooking.
Prepare small, thick dosas in batches.
Stack in hot box to keep warm.
Ready to serve.
howToServe: Serve Pundi Dosa with coconut chutney, jaggery-coconut mix, or chicken curry.

name: Benne Dosa
steps: Soak rice, urad dal, and poha for 4–5 hours.
Grind into smooth batter.
Ferment overnight.
Add salt and mix well.
Heat dosa tawa on high flame.
Pour a ladleful of batter and spread thin.
Immediately drop a spoonful of butter on top.
Spread butter evenly as dosa cooks.
Cook until edges turn crisp and golden.
Flip and cook the other side lightly.
Add more butter if desired.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Dosas should be thin, golden, and buttery.
Serve hot directly from pan.
Can also make slightly thick if preferred.
howToServe: Serve Benne Dosa hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or potato palya.

name: Pesarattu Dosa
ingredients: 1 cup whole green gram (moong dal, soaked overnight)
steps: Wash and soak moong dal and rice (if using) overnight or at least 6-7 hours.
Drain excess water and transfer to a blender.
Add green chilies, ginger, and coriander leaves to the blender.
Grind into a smooth batter using little water as required.
Ensure the batter is of pouring consistency (not too thick or runny).
Transfer to a bowl, add salt, and mix well.
Heat a dosa tawa or non-stick pan until hot.
Grease lightly with oil if required.
Pour a ladleful of batter in the center and spread it in circular motion like dosa.
Sprinkle finely chopped onions and cumin seeds on top.
Drizzle little oil around the edges.
Cook on medium flame until the edges turn golden and crisp.
Optionally, flip and cook the other side for 1 minute.
Remove from tawa carefully and serve hot.
Repeat with remaining batter to make more pesarattu dosas.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, ginger chutney, or sambar. Traditionally enjoyed as a wholesome breakfast in Mangalore-Udupi households.

name: Mangalore Ragi Dosa
steps: Mix ragi flour, rice flour, and urad dal batter in a bowl.
Add buttermilk and salt.
Adjust water to form a smooth dosa batter.
Allow the batter to ferment for 6–8 hours.
Heat a dosa tawa and grease lightly with oil.
Pour a ladle of batter and spread into a thin circle.
Drizzle oil around the edges.
Cook on medium flame until crisp.
Flip and cook lightly on the other side if desired.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Serve hot with chutney or sambar.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, tomato chutney, or vegetable sambar.

name: Surnoli Dosa
steps: Wash and soak raw rice with fenugreek seeds for 4–6 hours.
Wash and soak poha separately for 10–15 minutes before grinding.
Drain soaked rice and transfer to a mixer jar.
Add grated coconut, soaked poha, jaggery, and turmeric powder.
Grind into a smooth thick batter using little water as required.
Transfer the batter into a deep bowl.
Add salt to taste and mix well.
Cover and allow the batter to ferment overnight or at least 8–10 hours.
The next morning, mix the fermented batter gently without deflating it.
Heat a thick dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with ghee or oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter in the center without spreading too much.
Cover with a lid and cook on low-medium flame.
Surnoli dosa should be soft, spongy, and golden yellow with bubbles on top.
Do not flip; it is cooked only on one side.
Remove carefully and place on a serving plate.
Repeat for the remaining batter.
howToServe: Serve Surnoli dosa hot with homemade butter, ghee, or coconut chutney. Traditionally enjoyed as a sweet breakfast or tiffin in Udupi-Mangalore households.

name: Adai Dosa
steps: Wash and soak rice and all dals together for 3–4 hours.
Drain the soaked mixture and transfer to a grinder.
Add red chilies, cumin seeds, black pepper, and coconut to the grinder.
Grind into a coarse batter by adding water as required.
Add turmeric powder and salt to the batter.
Mix the batter well and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Heat a dosa tawa on medium flame until hot.
Grease the tawa lightly with oil or ghee.
Pour a ladleful of batter in the center of the tawa.
Spread into a thick dosa by rotating the ladle in circular motion.
Drizzle oil/ghee around the edges of the dosa.
Cook until the edges turn golden brown and crisp.
Flip the dosa and cook the other side for 1–2 minutes.
Remove from the tawa once cooked well.
Repeat with remaining batter.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve hot Adai Dosa with coconut chutney, jaggery, or butter.

name: Onion Dosa
steps: Prepare regular dosa batter using rice and urad dal.
Ferment the batter overnight until fluffy.
Heat a dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with oil or ghee.
Pour a ladle of batter in the center of the tawa.
Spread into a thin circular dosa.
Immediately sprinkle finely chopped onions evenly.
Sprinkle chopped green chilies and coriander leaves.
Add cumin seeds for extra flavor.
Press onions gently with spatula so they stick to dosa.
Drizzle oil/ghee around the edges.
Cook until the base becomes crisp and golden brown.
Flip the dosa carefully and cook for 1 minute.
Remove from the tawa and fold as desired.
Repeat the process with remaining batter.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Onion Dosa hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Ghee Roast Dosa
steps: Prepare dosa batter with rice and urad dal.
Ferment the batter overnight until airy.
Add salt and mix well before making dosas.
Heat a dosa tawa on high flame.
Pour a ladle of batter in the center of the tawa.
Spread into a very thin, large circle.
Reduce the flame slightly to medium.
Pour generous amount of ghee all around the dosa.
Spread ghee across the surface using spatula.
Cook until the dosa becomes crisp and golden.
Edges will begin to lift up slightly.
Do not flip the dosa, cook only on one side.
Fold the dosa into a triangle or roll shape.
Remove from tawa and place on a plate.
Repeat with remaining batter.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve Ghee Roast Dosa with red chutney, sambar, and coconut chutney.

name: Cheela (Kadle Bele Dosa)
steps: Wash and soak chana dal and rice for 3–4 hours.
Drain and transfer to a grinder.
Add green chilies, ginger, cumin seeds to grinder.
Grind into a smooth batter using little water.
Add turmeric powder and salt.
Mix well to form dosa batter consistency.
Heat a dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with oil.
Pour a ladle of batter in the center of the tawa.
Spread into a medium-thick dosa.
Drizzle oil around the edges.
Cook until the base turns golden brown.
Flip the dosa and cook the other side.
Once crisp and cooked, remove from tawa.
Repeat the process with remaining batter.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Kadle Bele Cheela hot with coconut chutney or tomato chutney.

name: Rava Dosa
steps: Combine rava, rice flour, and maida in a bowl.
Add cumin seeds, chopped green chilies, black pepper, and salt.
Mix dry ingredients thoroughly.
Add water slowly to form a thin, flowing batter.
Let the batter rest for 15–20 minutes.
Heat a dosa tawa on medium-high flame.
Grease lightly with oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter at the edges of the tawa in a circular motion.
Do not spread; let it flow naturally for lacy texture.
Drizzle oil around the edges and on the surface.
Cook until the underside turns golden brown and crisp.
Flip carefully if desired or cook single side traditionally.
Remove from tawa once crisp.
Repeat with remaining batter.
Serve immediately while hot and crisp.
Enjoy with coconut chutney and sambar.
howToServe: Serve Rava Dosa hot with coconut chutney, tomato chutney, or sambar.

name: Eggless Cheese Dosa
steps: Prepare fermented dosa batter.
Heat a dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with oil or ghee.
Pour a ladle of batter in the center.
Spread into a thin circular dosa.
Sprinkle chopped onions, green chilies, and coriander leaves on top.
Add grated cheese evenly over the dosa.
Drizzle a little oil around edges.
Cook until the base turns golden and crisp.
Optionally cover with a lid for 1–2 minutes to melt cheese.
Check that cheese is melted but dosa remains crisp.
Flip gently if desired or serve single-side folded.
Remove from tawa carefully.
Repeat the process with remaining batter.
Serve hot immediately.
Enjoy cheesy, crispy dosa.
howToServe: Serve Eggless Cheese Dosa with tomato or mint chutney.

name: Mixed Vegetable Dosa
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds; let them splutter.
Add chopped onion and green chili; sauté until soft.
Add cabbage, carrot, and capsicum.
Sauté for 3–4 minutes until vegetables are slightly tender.
Add salt and chopped coriander; mix well.
Keep vegetable filling aside.
Heat dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with oil.
Pour a ladle of dosa batter and spread into a thin circle.
Place prepared vegetable mixture evenly on the dosa.
Drizzle a little oil around edges.
Cook until base turns golden brown and crisp.
Fold the dosa over the vegetable filling.
Remove from tawa carefully.
Repeat with remaining batter and filling.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Mixed Vegetable Dosa with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Avarekalu Dosa
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped onions and green chili; sauté until soft.
Add boiled hyacinth beans and turmeric powder.
Mash beans lightly and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add salt and chopped coriander; mix well.
Keep the bean filling aside.
Heat dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with oil.
Pour a ladle of dosa batter and spread into thin circle.
Place avarekalu filling evenly on the dosa.
Drizzle oil around the edges.
Cook until base turns golden brown and crisp.
Fold the dosa carefully over filling.
Remove from tawa.
Serve immediately.
Repeat for remaining batter and filling.
howToServe: Serve Avarekalu Dosa hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Carrot Dosa (Gajjar Dosa)
steps: Prepare fermented dosa batter.
Heat a dosa tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with oil or ghee.
Pour a ladle of batter on the tawa and spread into a thin circle.
Evenly sprinkle grated carrot on top of the dosa.
Add finely chopped onions and green chilies.
Sprinkle cumin seeds and chopped coriander over the dosa.
Press gently with a spatula so vegetables stick.
Drizzle oil or ghee around edges.
Cook until base turns golden brown and crisp.
Flip carefully and cook the other side for 1–2 minutes (optional).
Remove dosa from the tawa once cooked.
Fold or roll the dosa as desired.
Repeat with remaining batter and carrot mixture.
Serve hot immediately.
Enjoy fresh and healthy Carrot Dosa with chutney or sambar.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, tomato chutney, or sambar.

name: Toor Dal Sambar
steps: Wash toor dal thoroughly.
Pressure cook dal with turmeric powder and enough water until soft (3–4 whistles).
Soak tamarind in warm water for 15–20 minutes and extract pulp.
Heat oil in a pan for tempering.
Add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Sauté until aromatic.
Add chopped vegetables and sauté lightly for 2–3 minutes.
Add tamarind extract and bring to a boil.
Add cooked dal to the tamarind-vegetable mix.
Add sambar powder and salt to taste.
Simmer on low flame for 10–15 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Check consistency; add water if needed for desired thickness.
Mash dal lightly for smooth texture.
Adjust seasoning with salt and sambar powder if required.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes before serving.
Stir gently before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with steamed rice, idli, dosa, or vada. Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.

name: Drumstick Sambar
steps: Wash toor dal thoroughly and pressure cook with turmeric until soft.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Once aromatic, add chopped tomatoes and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped drumsticks and stir lightly.
Add tamarind paste and 1 cup water; bring to boil.
Add cooked dal to the pan.
Mix in sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 15–20 minutes until drumsticks are tender.
Mash dal slightly for a smooth texture.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
Add water for desired consistency.
Simmer for 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Stir gently before serving.
Optional: garnish with coriander leaves.
howToServe: Serve hot with steamed rice, dosa, or idli. Ideal for a traditional Udupi meal.

name: Ridge Gourd Sambar (Bele Hasi Sambar)
steps: Wash toor dal thoroughly and pressure cook with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water for 15–20 minutes and extract juice.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Once aromatic, add chopped tomatoes and sauté 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped ridge gourd and sauté lightly.
Add tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 15–20 minutes until ridge gourd is tender.
Mash dal lightly for smooth texture.
Adjust water to desired consistency.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
Simmer 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with plain rice, idli, or dosa.

name: Snake Gourd Sambar (Padwal Sambar)
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract juice.
Heat oil and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped snake gourd and sauté lightly.
Pour tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 15–20 minutes until gourd is tender.
Mash dal slightly for smooth texture.
Adjust water to achieve desired consistency.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
Simmer 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with plain rice, dosa, or idli.

name: Tomato Sambar
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract juice.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté until soft.
Pour tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 10–15 minutes.
Mash dal lightly for smooth texture.
Adjust water to desired consistency.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
Simmer 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves before serving.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with steamed rice, idli, or dosa.

name: Carrot & Beans Sambar
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with 1 cup water and turmeric powder until soft.
Soak tamarind in 1/2 cup warm water and extract juice.
Heat a pan with oil, add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, dried red chilies, and hing; sauté for a few seconds.
Add chopped carrot and beans; sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped tomato and cook for another 2 minutes.
Pour tamarind extract and 1 cup water into the pan.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 5 minutes.
Mash the cooked dal slightly and add to the vegetables.
Add sambar powder and salt; mix well.
Simmer on low flame for 5–7 minutes.
Adjust consistency by adding water if needed.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Turn off the flame and let it rest for a couple of minutes.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Carrot & Beans Sambar with steamed rice, idli, dosa, or vada.

name: Mixed Vegetable Sambar
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrot, beans, peas, drumstick)
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract juice.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add all chopped vegetables and sauté lightly.
Add tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 15–20 minutes until vegetables are cooked.
Mash dal slightly for smooth texture.
Check consistency and adjust with water.
Adjust salt to taste.
Simmer 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves before serving.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Mixed Vegetable Sambar with steamed rice, dosa, or idli.

name: Onion Sambar
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract juice.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped onions and sauté until caramelized (10–12 minutes).
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Pour tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 10–15 minutes.
Mash dal lightly for smooth texture.
Adjust water to desired consistency.
Check seasoning and adjust salt if needed.
Simmer for 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Onion Sambar with steamed rice or idli.

name: Brinjal Sambar
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract juice.
Heat oil and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped brinjals and sauté lightly.
Add tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add sambar powder and salt.
Simmer on low flame for 15–20 minutes until brinjals are tender.
Mash dal lightly for smooth texture.
Adjust water to desired consistency.
Check seasoning and adjust salt.
Simmer 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves before serving.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Brinjal Sambar with steamed rice, dosa, or idli.

name: Tender Coconut Sambar
steps: Wash and pressure cook toor dal with turmeric until soft.
Soak tamarind in warm water and extract juice.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, fenugreek seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add chopped tomatoes and sauté 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped vegetables and sauté lightly.
Pour tamarind extract and bring to boil.
Add cooked dal and mix well.
Add grated tender coconut, tender coconut water, and sambar powder.
Mix thoroughly and simmer for 10–15 minutes until vegetables are tender.
Mash dal lightly for smooth texture.
Adjust water for desired consistency.
Check seasoning and adjust salt.
Simmer 5 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let sambar rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve Tender Coconut Sambar with steamed rice, dosa, or idli.

name: Tomato Rasam
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies and crushed garlic.
Sauté until garlic turns golden brown.
Add chopped tomatoes and slit green chilies.
Cook for 5–6 minutes until tomatoes soften.
Add turmeric powder, coarsely ground black pepper, and cumin seeds.
Mix well and sauté for another 2 minutes.
Pour tamarind extract and 2 cups water into the pan.
Bring the mixture to a boil.
Reduce flame and simmer for 10 minutes.
Mash tomatoes lightly with a ladle for smooth texture.
Check salt and adjust if necessary.
Add chopped coriander leaves and mix well.
Simmer for 2–3 more minutes.
Turn off flame and let rasam rest for a few minutes.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Tomato Rasam with steamed rice or as a warm soup.

name: Garlic Rasam (Poondu Rasam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies and crushed garlic.
Sauté until garlic is aromatic and slightly golden.
Add turmeric powder, black pepper, and cumin seeds.
Pour tamarind extract and 2 cups water into the pan.
Bring to a gentle boil.
Reduce flame and simmer for 10 minutes.
Mash lightly to mix flavors well.
Check salt and adjust if needed.
Add chopped coriander leaves and mix.
Simmer for another 2–3 minutes.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes to infuse flavors.
Serve hot immediately.
Optional: drizzle a little ghee before serving.
Pair with steamed rice or drink as a warming soup.
Enjoy the strong garlic flavor.
howToServe: Serve Garlic Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a light soup.

name: Pepper Rasam (Milagu Rasam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and fenugreek seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies.
Add coarsely crushed black pepper and cumin seeds.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes for aroma.
Pour tamarind extract and 2 cups water.
Add turmeric powder and salt.
Bring to a boil and then simmer for 10–12 minutes.
Mash lightly with a ladle to mix flavors.
Add chopped coriander leaves and mix.
Simmer for 2–3 more minutes.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Taste and adjust salt or pepper if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Enjoy the warming and spicy rasam.
Pairs well with plain rice or can be drunk as soup.
Optionally garnish with curry leaves.
howToServe: Serve Pepper Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a spicy soup.

name: Lemon Rasam (Nimbu Rasam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies, cumin seeds, and black pepper.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract along with 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 8–10 minutes.
Mash lightly to mix flavors.
Add lemon juice and stir gently.
Add salt to taste.
Simmer for another 2–3 minutes on low flame.
Turn off flame and add chopped coriander leaves.
Cover for 2–3 minutes to infuse flavors.
Taste and adjust lemon or salt if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Enjoy the tangy and refreshing rasam.
Can be served with steamed rice or drunk as soup.
Optionally, drizzle a little ghee on top.
howToServe: Serve Lemon Rasam hot with steamed rice or enjoy as a light soup.

name: Tamarind Rasam (Puliyodarai Rasam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies, cumin seeds, and black pepper.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes to release aroma.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract with 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 10–12 minutes.
Mash lightly to mix flavors well.
Check salt and adjust as needed.
Add chopped coriander leaves and stir.
Simmer on low flame for 2–3 more minutes.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Serve hot immediately.
Enjoy the tangy, flavorful rasam.
Pairs well with steamed rice or can be drunk as soup.
Optionally garnish with a few curry leaves on top.
Keep warm until serving.
Best enjoyed fresh.
howToServe: Serve Tamarind Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a light soup.

name: Coriander Rasam
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies and cumin seeds.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes until aromatic.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract with 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 10 minutes.
Mash lightly to blend flavors.
Add coarsely ground black pepper and salt.
Stir well and simmer for another 3–4 minutes.
Add chopped coriander leaves and mix thoroughly.
Simmer for 2 more minutes to infuse aroma.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Check seasoning and adjust salt if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Pairs well with steamed rice or can be consumed as soup.
Optionally, drizzle a few drops of ghee before serving.
Enjoy the refreshing coriander aroma.
howToServe: Serve Coriander Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a light soup.

name: Mint Rasam (Pudina Rasam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies and cumin seeds.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes until aromatic.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract with 2 cups water.
Bring to a gentle boil and simmer for 8–10 minutes.
Mash lightly to blend flavors.
Add coarsely ground black pepper and salt.
Stir well and simmer for 2–3 minutes.
Add chopped fresh mint leaves.
Simmer for another 2–3 minutes to infuse mint aroma.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Check seasoning and adjust salt if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Pairs well with steamed rice or can be drunk as soup.
Optionally garnish with a few mint leaves on top.
Enjoy the unique mint flavor.
howToServe: Serve Mint Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a refreshing soup.

name: Horse Gram Rasam (Kollu Rasam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies and cumin seeds.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes until aromatic.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract with 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 10 minutes.
Add cooked horse gram and mash slightly.
Add coarsely ground black pepper and salt.
Simmer for 5–6 minutes on low flame.
Stir occasionally to blend flavors.
Add chopped coriander leaves and mix well.
Simmer for another 2–3 minutes.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Check seasoning and adjust salt if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Pairs well with steamed rice or as a hearty soup.
Optionally drizzle a little ghee before serving.
howToServe: Serve Horse Gram Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a nutritious soup.

name: Coconut Rasam
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies, cumin seeds, and black pepper.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes until aromatic.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract with 2 cups water.
Bring to a boil and simmer for 8–10 minutes.
Grind grated coconut with little water to form a smooth paste.
Add coconut paste to the simmering rasam.
Stir well to blend flavors.
Simmer for 3–4 minutes on low flame.
Add salt to taste and chopped coriander leaves.
Mix thoroughly and simmer for 2 more minutes.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Pairs well with steamed rice or can be drunk as a light soup.
Enjoy the coastal coconut flavor.
howToServe: Serve Coconut Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a light, sweetish soup.

name: Green Chili Rasam
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds.
Once they splutter, add dried red chilies, cumin seeds, and black pepper.
Sauté for 1–2 minutes until aromatic.
Add turmeric powder and tamarind extract with 2 cups water.
Bring to a gentle boil and simmer for 8–10 minutes.
Add chopped green chilies and stir well.
Simmer on low flame for 5–6 minutes.
Mash lightly to mix flavors.
Add salt to taste and chopped coriander leaves.
Simmer for 2–3 more minutes.
Turn off flame and cover for 5 minutes.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or spice if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Pairs well with steamed rice or can be consumed as a spicy soup.
Optionally, drizzle a few drops of ghee before serving.
Enjoy the spicy, pungent flavor.
howToServe: Serve Green Chili Rasam hot with steamed rice or as a spicy soup.

name: Ven Pongal
steps: Wash rice and moong dal together.
Cook rice and dal in water until soft and mushy.
Heat ghee in a small pan.
Add cumin seeds, grated ginger, black pepper, cashews, and curry leaves.
Sauté until cashews turn golden.
Add the tempering to cooked rice and dal mixture.
Mix gently to combine.
Adjust salt to taste.
Mash lightly if needed for smooth consistency.
Serve hot in a bowl.
howToServe: Serve Ven Pongal with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Curd Rice (Thayir Sadam)
ingredients: Optional: grated carrot or pomegranate seeds for garnish
steps: Cook rice and let it cool slightly.
Mash rice lightly if needed.
Add yogurt to rice and mix well.
Heat oil in a small pan.
Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, curry leaves, and green chilies.
Allow seeds to splutter.
Pour the tempering over the curd rice.
Add salt and mix thoroughly.
Garnish with coriander leaves.
Optional: add grated carrot or pomegranate seeds.
Serve immediately or chilled.
howToServe: Serve Curd Rice with pickle, papadam, or fried curry leaves.

name: Lemon Rice (Chitranna)
steps: Cook rice and let it cool slightly.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Add chopped green chilies and sauté briefly.
Add turmeric powder and mix.
Pour the mixture over cooked rice.
Add lemon juice and salt.
Mix gently to coat rice evenly.
Add roasted peanuts for crunch.
Garnish with fresh curry leaves.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve Lemon Rice with papadam, pickle, or raita.

name: Coconut Rice (Thengai Sadam)
steps: Cook rice and let it cool slightly.
Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, urad dal, cashews, and curry leaves.
Sauté until cashews turn golden.
Add chopped green chilies and grated coconut.
Sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add the coconut mixture to cooked rice.
Add salt and mix thoroughly.
Ensure rice grains remain separate.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Coconut Rice with sambar, rasam, or papadam.

name: Tamarind Rice (Puliyodarai / Puliyamanna)
steps: Cook rice and let it cool slightly.
Heat oil in a pan for tempering.
Add mustard seeds, urad dal, and dried red chilies; let them splutter.
Add curry leaves and sauté briefly.
Add tamarind paste, turmeric powder, and jaggery; mix well.
Cook for 2–3 minutes to blend flavors.
Add rice and salt.
Mix thoroughly so tamarind paste coats rice evenly.
Ensure rice grains remain separate and not mushy.
Cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Adjust salt if needed.
Garnish with curry leaves.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Tamarind Rice with papadam, fried peanuts, or a side vegetable curry.

name: Bisibele Bath
steps: Cook rice and toor dal together until soft.
Prepare tamarind extract and keep aside.
Heat oil and ghee in a pan.
Add mustard seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves; let them splutter.
Add turmeric powder and bisibele bath powder; sauté briefly.
Pour in tamarind extract and salt; bring to a boil.
Add cooked rice and dal mixture to the tamarind gravy.
Mix gently to combine all ingredients.
Cook on low flame for 5–7 minutes for flavors to blend.
Adjust consistency by adding water if needed.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Bisibele Bath with papadam, ghee, or a side pickle.

name: Vegetable Biryani
steps: Wash and soak basmati rice for 20 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan; add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté briefly.
Add chopped vegetables, turmeric powder, and salt; cook for 5 minutes.
Add soaked rice and mix gently.
Pour water and bring to a boil.
Reduce flame, cover, and cook until rice is done and water absorbed.
Sprinkle garam masala, chopped coriander, and mint leaves.
Mix gently to combine flavors.
Let it rest covered for 5 minutes.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Vegetable Biryani with raita, pickle, or papadam.

name: Tomato Rice
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and curry leaves.
Add chopped onions and sauté until translucent.
Add green chilies and chopped tomatoes; cook until soft.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Add cooked rice to the tomato mixture.
Mix gently to coat the rice evenly with tomato masala.
Cook on low flame for 3–4 minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Tomato Rice with papadam, raita, or a side vegetable curry.

name: Curd Tamarind Rice
steps: Cook rice and let it cool slightly.
Heat oil and add mustard seeds, dried red chilies, and curry leaves.
Add turmeric powder and sauté briefly.
Mix tamarind paste with the tempering and cook for 2 minutes.
Add yogurt to the cooked rice and stir gently.
Pour the tamarind-tempering mixture over rice.
Mix well to coat rice evenly.
Adjust salt to taste.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve Curd Tamarind Rice with papadam or fried curry leaves.

name: Mango Rice (Mambazha Sadam)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and add mustard seeds and curry leaves.
Add chopped green chilies and sauté briefly.
Add grated raw mango and turmeric powder; cook for 2–3 minutes.
Add cooked rice and salt.
Mix gently to combine rice with mango masala evenly.
Add roasted peanuts and chopped coriander leaves.
Cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Mango Rice with papadam or yogurt.

name: Ghee Rice (Neivedhyam Rice)
steps: Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan.
Add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add green cardamoms, cloves, and cinnamon stick; sauté for 30 seconds.
Add cashews and fry until golden brown.
Add raisins and sauté until they puff up.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Gently mix the rice with spices and ghee without breaking the grains.
Add salt to taste.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves over the rice.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Check the texture of rice and add 2–3 tbsp water if grains seem dry.
Gently fluff the rice with a spatula.
Ensure rice is evenly coated with ghee and aromatic spices.
Remove from heat and let it rest covered for 1–2 minutes.
Taste and adjust salt if needed.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Ghee Rice with sambar, rasam, or any vegetable curry.

name: Mint Rice (Pudina Sadam)
steps: Wash mint and coriander leaves thoroughly.
Grind mint, coriander, green chilies, and ginger into a fine paste.
Heat oil or ghee in a pan.
Add mustard seeds and cumin seeds; let them splutter.
Add dried red chilies and sauté for a few seconds.
Add turmeric powder and mix well.
Add the mint-coriander paste and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add salt to taste.
Add cooked rice and mix gently with the paste.
Ensure rice grains are coated evenly with the mint mixture.
Add roasted cashews and fold gently.
Optionally, sprinkle lemon juice for tanginess.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2 minutes.
Garnish with chopped onions.
Fluff rice gently and serve hot.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
howToServe: Serve Mint Rice with curd, raita, or a mild vegetable curry.

name: Carrot Rice
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, green chilies, and curry leaves; sauté for a few seconds.
Add grated carrots and sauté for 3–4 minutes.
Add turmeric powder and ginger paste; mix well.
Cook until carrots are slightly tender.
Add roasted cashews and fold gently.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Mix rice carefully so that it doesn’t break.
Add salt to taste.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Optionally, add lemon juice for tanginess.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Fluff the rice gently before serving.
Ensure all rice grains are coated with spices and carrot.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Carrot Rice with raita, papad, or a mild vegetable curry.

name: Mushroom Rice
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds and chopped green chili; sauté for a few seconds.
Add ginger paste and sauté briefly.
Add chopped mushrooms and cook until tender.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Add roasted cashews and fold gently.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Mix gently to combine mushrooms with rice.
Ensure rice grains remain separate.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves over the rice.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Adjust salt if needed.
Fluff rice gently before serving.
Serve hot immediately.
Enjoy the aromatic mushroom rice.
howToServe: Serve Mushroom Rice with vegetable kurma or simple raita.

name: Cashew & Coconut Rice
steps: Heat oil or ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, green chilies, and curry leaves; sauté for a few seconds.
Add grated coconut and fry lightly until aromatic.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Add roasted cashews and fold gently.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Mix gently to coat rice with coconut and spices.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves over the rice.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Fluff the rice gently before serving.
Ensure rice grains are separate and evenly coated.
Taste and adjust salt if necessary.
Serve hot immediately.
Repeat for larger portions if required.
howToServe: Serve Cashew & Coconut Rice with vegetable kurma, sambar, or raita.

name: Menthya Rice
steps: Heat oil or ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, chopped green chilies, and curry leaves; sauté briefly.
Add ginger paste and sauté for a few seconds.
Add chopped mint leaves and sauté for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Add roasted cashews and stir gently.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Mix rice carefully so that it is evenly coated with mint and spices.
Ensure rice grains remain separate and fluffy.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Optionally, add lemon juice for a tangy flavor.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Fluff the rice gently before serving.
Serve hot immediately.
Repeat for larger portions if needed.
howToServe: Serve Menthya Rice hot with raita, sambar, or vegetable curry.

name: Kadalekayi Sadam
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, chopped green chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida; sauté briefly.
Add ginger paste and sauté for a few seconds.
Add roasted peanuts and sauté for 1–2 minutes.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Gently mix so rice is coated with spices and peanuts.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Optionally, add grated coconut and mix lightly.
Ensure rice grains remain separate and fluffy.
Cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Fluff the rice gently before serving.
Check for salt and adjust if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
Repeat steps for larger portions if required.
howToServe: Serve Kadalekayi Sadam hot with papadam, pickle, or raita.

name: Beetroot Rice
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, chopped green chilies, curry leaves, and asafoetida; sauté briefly.
Add ginger paste and sauté for a few seconds.
Add grated beetroot and sauté for 5–6 minutes until slightly tender.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Gently mix so rice is evenly colored with beetroot.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Optionally, add grated coconut and mix lightly.
Ensure rice grains remain separate and fluffy.
Cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Fluff the rice gently before serving.
Check for salt and adjust if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve Beetroot Rice hot with raita, papadam, or pickle.

name: Horse Gram Rice (Kollu Sambar Rice)
steps: Boil horse gram dal until soft.
Mash dal slightly and set aside.
Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds, cumin seeds, and dried red chilies; let them splutter.
Add curry leaves and sauté briefly.
Add tamarind paste and turmeric powder; mix well.
Add mashed horse gram dal to the pan.
Add salt to taste.
Cook for 5 minutes until flavors blend.
Add cooked rice and mix gently.
Ensure rice grains are coated evenly with sambar.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Cover and cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Fluff gently before serving.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Horse Gram Rice with papad or pickles for a wholesome meal.

name: Gongura Rice
ingredients: 1 cup gongura leaves (sorrel leaves), cleaned and chopped
steps: Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add cumin seeds, dried red chilies, green chilies, and asafoetida; sauté briefly.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for a few seconds.
Add chopped gongura leaves and sauté for 5–7 minutes until soft.
Add turmeric powder and salt; mix well.
Optionally, add jaggery for slight sweetness and mix.
Add cooked rice to the pan.
Gently mix so rice is evenly combined with gongura leaves.
Sprinkle chopped coriander leaves.
Optionally, add grated coconut and mix lightly.
Ensure rice grains remain separate and fluffy.
Cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Check for salt and adjust if needed.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve Gongura Rice hot with papadam, raita, or spicy pickle.

name: Kesari Bath
steps: Heat ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add cashews and raisins; fry until golden and set aside.
In the same pan, roast semolina until aromatic.
Boil water in a separate pan.
Slowly add boiling water to roasted semolina, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Cook until semolina absorbs water and softens.
Add sugar and mix well.
Add saffron strands and cardamom powder; stir to combine.
Cook for 2–3 minutes until mixture thickens.
Add fried cashews and raisins; mix gently.
Adjust consistency with a little water if needed.
Simmer for 1–2 minutes.
Turn off flame and let it rest for 5 minutes.
Stir gently before serving.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve Kesari Bath warm or at room temperature, garnished with fried cashews and raisins.

name: Obbattu
steps: Cook chana dal until soft and drain excess water.
Grind cooked dal to a smooth paste.
Add jaggery and cardamom powder to dal paste; mix well.
Prepare dough by mixing flour and water; knead to soft consistency.
Divide dough and filling into equal portions.
Roll dough into small circles.
Place filling in center and fold dough over it.
Gently roll to form thin stuffed flatbread.
Heat tawa on medium flame.
Grease lightly with ghee or oil.
Cook the rolled flatbread on tawa until golden brown on both sides.
Apply ghee while cooking for richness.
Repeat with remaining portions.
Ensure even cooking to avoid burning.
Serve hot.
howToServe: Serve Obbattu warm with ghee, often accompanied by milk or coconut chutney.

name: Mysore Pak
steps: Grease a plate or tray with ghee and set aside.
Heat sugar and water in a pan to form sugar syrup (one-string consistency).
Add gram flour gradually to syrup, stirring continuously to avoid lumps.
Add ghee slowly in small portions while stirring.
Continue to cook on low flame until mixture leaves sides of the pan.
Check consistency; mixture should form soft balls.
Pour mixture into greased plate immediately.
Level the surface with spatula.
Allow it to cool slightly for 5–10 minutes.
Cut into desired pieces while warm.
Let it cool completely to set.
Remove pieces carefully from tray.
Serve at room temperature.
Store in airtight container for a few days.
Enjoy the rich, melt-in-mouth texture.
howToServe: Serve Mysore Pak at room temperature as a festive sweet.

name: Coconut Laddoo
steps: Heat ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add grated coconut and roast lightly for 2–3 minutes.
Add jaggery and stir continuously until it melts.
Cook until mixture thickens slightly.
Add cardamom powder and mix well.
Optionally, add chopped nuts for texture.
Remove from heat and let mixture cool slightly.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take small portions of mixture and roll into round balls.
Place laddoos on a plate.
Let them cool completely to firm up.
Store in an airtight container.
Repeat for remaining mixture.
Ensure laddoos are uniform in size.
Serve or gift as festive treat.
howToServe: Serve Coconut Laddoo at room temperature as a sweet snack or festive dessert.

name: Sakkarai Pongal
steps: Wash rice and moong dal thoroughly.
Cook rice and dal together with 3 cups water until soft and mushy.
Grind jaggery with little water to make syrup.
Add jaggery syrup to cooked rice and dal mixture.
Cook on low flame until mixture thickens.
Heat ghee in a small pan and fry cashews and raisins until golden.
Add fried cashews and raisins to Pongal.
Add cardamom powder and mix well.
Cook for another 2–3 minutes.
Check consistency; it should be soft and slightly thick.
Adjust sweetness if needed.
Turn off flame and let it rest for a few minutes.
Stir gently before serving.
Serve warm for best taste.
Can garnish with extra ghee if desired.
howToServe: Serve Sakkarai Pongal warm as a festive sweet or offering.

name: Vermicelli Payasam
steps: Wash rice or vermicelli thoroughly.
Boil water in a pan and cook rice or vermicelli until soft.
Drain excess water if using rice.
Add grated jaggery to the cooked rice/vermicelli and mix well.
Pour in coconut milk slowly, stirring continuously.
Cook on low flame until mixture thickens slightly.
Heat ghee in a small pan.
Fry cashews and raisins until golden.
Add fried cashews and raisins to payasam.
Add cardamom powder and stir gently.
Simmer for 2–3 minutes.
Ensure payasam is creamy and well-blended.
Check sweetness and adjust if needed.
Turn off flame and let it rest for a few minutes.
Serve warm or chilled as desired.
howToServe: Serve Paayasam warm or chilled, garnished with fried cashews and raisins.

name: Neer Laddoo
steps: Mix rice flour and grated coconut in a bowl.
Add sugar/jaggery and cardamom powder.
Add water gradually to form a soft dough.
Ensure dough is pliable and not sticky.
Grease hands lightly with ghee or oil.
Take small portions of dough and roll into smooth balls.
Arrange laddoos on a plate.
Steam the laddoos in a steamer for 5–7 minutes.
Remove from steamer and let them cool slightly.
Check consistency; laddoos should be soft but hold shape.
Repeat with remaining dough.
Store in an airtight container.
Serve at room temperature.
Perfect for festivals and offerings.
Enjoy soft, melt-in-mouth texture.
howToServe: Serve Neer Laddoo at room temperature as a light, sweet snack.

name: Rava Laddoo
steps: Heat ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add semolina and roast until aromatic and lightly golden.
Add grated coconut and roast for 2 minutes.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Mix in grated jaggery and cardamom powder.
Ensure mixture is warm enough to shape.
Grease hands lightly with ghee.
Take small portions of mixture and roll into round laddoos.
Optionally press nuts on top of laddoos for decoration.
Arrange laddoos on a plate.
Allow to cool completely.
Store in airtight container.
Repeat for remaining mixture.
Check for uniform size and shape.
Serve as a festive sweet.
howToServe: Serve Rava Laddoo at room temperature with tea or as a festive treat.

name: Coconut Halwa
steps: Heat ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add cashews and raisins; fry until golden and remove.
Add grated coconut to the ghee and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Add sugar and stir continuously until it melts and blends with coconut.
Cook on low flame until mixture thickens.
Add cardamom powder and mix well.
Add fried cashews and raisins; combine gently.
Continue to cook until mixture leaves sides of pan.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Grease a plate with ghee.
Transfer halwa to plate and spread evenly.
Allow to set for a few minutes.
Cut into desired pieces if needed.
Serve warm or at room temperature.
Store leftovers in airtight container.
howToServe: Serve Coconut Halwa warm or at room temperature as a rich dessert.

name: Badam / Almond Halwa
steps: Soak almonds in warm water for 2–3 hours and peel them.
Grind almonds to a smooth paste using little milk.
Heat ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add almond paste and cook, stirring continuously.
Add remaining milk gradually while stirring.
Cook until mixture thickens.
Add sugar and mix well.
Cook on low flame until halwa reaches desired consistency.
Add cardamom powder and saffron strands if using.
Stir continuously to avoid sticking.
Ensure halwa is glossy and smooth.
Remove from heat and let it cool slightly.
Grease a plate lightly with ghee and pour halwa to set.
Cut into pieces if desired.
Serve warm or at room temperature.
howToServe: Serve Badam Halwa warm as a festive sweet or dessert.

name: Thengai Poli (Coconut Sweet Flatbread)
steps: Grate fresh coconut and mix with jaggery.
Add cardamom powder and mix well for filling.
Mix rice flour with a little water to form soft dough.
Divide dough into small balls.
Roll each ball into a small circle on a greased surface.
Place a portion of coconut-jaggery filling in the center.
Fold edges over filling and gently flatten.
Heat a tawa or flat pan on medium flame.
Grease lightly with ghee.
Cook each poli until golden on both sides.
Flip carefully to avoid spilling filling.
Brush with ghee while cooking for aroma.
Ensure filling remains soft and intact.
Remove from pan and let it cool slightly.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve Thengai Poli warm with a dollop of ghee.

name: Rice & Coconut Payasam
steps: Wash rice thoroughly.
Boil water and cook rice until soft.
Add jaggery to the cooked rice and stir until dissolved.
Slowly add coconut milk while stirring.
Cook on low flame until mixture thickens slightly.
Heat ghee in a small pan.
Fry cashews and raisins until golden.
Add fried cashews and raisins to payasam.
Add cardamom powder and mix well.
Simmer for 2–3 minutes to blend flavors.
Check sweetness and adjust if needed.
Ensure consistency is creamy, not watery.
Turn off flame and let it rest.
Serve warm or chilled as preferred.
Enjoy the rich, sweet flavor.
howToServe: Serve Rice & Coconut Payasam warm or chilled, garnished with cashews and raisins.

name: Ellu Urundai
steps: Roast sesame seeds lightly until aromatic.
Heat jaggery with water in a pan until it melts into syrup.
Stir continuously to avoid burning.
Add ghee to the syrup and mix well.
Add roasted sesame seeds to jaggery syrup.
Mix quickly to coat seeds evenly.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take small portions of mixture and roll into smooth balls.
Place balls on a greased plate.
Allow to cool and set completely.
Ensure balls hold shape and are not sticky.
Store in an airtight container.
Repeat for remaining mixture.
Perfect for festive occasions like Sankranti.
Enjoy crunchy and sweet sesame balls.
howToServe: Serve Ellu Urundai as a sweet snack or festival treat.

name: Modak
steps: Prepare filling by mixing grated coconut, jaggery, and cardamom powder.
Boil water with a pinch of salt and ghee.
Add rice flour to boiling water gradually, stirring continuously.
Cook until dough forms and is smooth.
Let the dough cool slightly.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take small portions of dough and flatten into small discs.
Place filling in the center of each disc.
Fold and shape into modak (round or conical).
Grease steamer plate with ghee.
Arrange modaks in steamer without touching.
Steam for 10–12 minutes on medium flame.
Remove carefully and let cool slightly.
Ensure modaks hold shape after steaming.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve Modak warm with a drizzle of ghee.

name: Chiroti
steps: Mix flour, ghee, and water to form a soft dough.
Rest the dough for 15–20 minutes.
Roll out dough into thin sheets.
Cut into desired size squares or circles.
Layer 3–4 sheets, brushing each with ghee.
Press gently to combine layers.
Heat oil or ghee in a pan for deep frying.
Fry layered dough until golden brown and crisp.
Remove and drain excess oil.
Dust generously with powdered sugar and cardamom powder.
Repeat for remaining dough.
Ensure layers remain crisp and flaky.
Serve warm immediately.
Perfect as a festive treat.
Store in airtight container for later use.
howToServe: Serve Chiroti warm or at room temperature as a sweet snack or dessert.

name: Kozhukattai Sweet Rice Balls
steps: Prepare filling by mixing grated coconut, jaggery, and cardamom powder.
Boil water with a pinch of salt and ghee.
Add rice flour gradually to boiling water, stirring continuously.
Cook until smooth dough forms.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take small portions of dough and flatten into discs.
Place filling in the center of each disc.
Fold and seal to form round balls.
Grease steamer plate lightly with ghee.
Arrange balls in steamer without touching each other.
Steam for 10–12 minutes on medium flame.
Check if balls are cooked through and firm.
Remove carefully and cool slightly.
Ensure shape remains intact after steaming.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve Kozhukattai Sweet Rice Balls warm with a drizzle of ghee.

name: Neivedya Rice
steps: Cook rice and let it cool slightly.
Heat ghee in a pan and fry cashews and raisins until golden.
Add jaggery or sugar to the pan and melt slightly.
Add cooked rice and mix thoroughly.
Ensure jaggery coats rice evenly.
Add cardamom powder and grated coconut if using.
Mix gently to combine flavors.
Cook on low flame for 2–3 minutes.
Check for sweetness and adjust if needed.
Ensure rice grains remain separate.
Remove from heat.
Transfer to serving bowl.
Garnish with fried cashews and raisins.
Serve slightly warm or at room temperature.
Perfect for temple offerings or festive occasions.
howToServe: Serve Neivedya Rice as prasad or sweet dish during festivals.

name: Mangalore Bun (Sweet Banana Bun)
steps: Mash ripe bananas until smooth.
Add sugar, milk, and cardamom powder; mix well.
Sift flour and baking powder, then add to banana mixture.
Knead into soft, slightly sticky dough.
Divide dough into small portions.
Roll each portion into flat discs or oval shapes.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Fry buns until golden brown on both sides.
Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels.
Repeat for remaining dough portions.
Ensure buns are cooked through and fluffy.
Cool slightly before serving.
Store in airtight container if needed.
Perfect for breakfast or evening snack.
Enjoy soft and sweet flavor.
howToServe: Serve Mangalore Bun warm with tea or coffee.

name: Coconut & Jaggery Laddoo with Cardamom
steps: Heat ghee in a pan.
Add grated coconut and roast lightly for 2–3 minutes.
Add jaggery and stir until melted.
Mix well so coconut is coated with jaggery.
Add cardamom powder and combine.
Cook for 3–4 minutes on low flame.
Remove from heat and let cool slightly.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take small portions and roll into round laddoos.
Place on a plate to set.
Ensure laddoos are firm and hold shape.
Repeat for remaining mixture.
Allow to cool completely before storing.
Store in airtight container for up to a week.
Ideal as festive treat.
howToServe: Serve Coconut & Jaggery Laddoo warm or at room temperature.

name: Ragi Jaggery Laddoo
steps: Dry roast ragi flour in a pan for 4–5 minutes on low flame.
Heat ghee in another pan.
Add grated jaggery and melt gently.
Mix jaggery with roasted ragi flour.
Add grated coconut and cardamom powder.
Combine thoroughly into a uniform mixture.
Grease hands with ghee.
Take small portions and roll into round laddoos.
Place laddoos on a plate to set.
Allow to cool slightly to firm up.
Ensure laddoos hold shape.
Repeat for remaining mixture.
Store in airtight container for later use.
Perfect for healthy festive snack.
Enjoy the nutritious and sweet flavor.
howToServe: Serve Ragi Jaggery Laddoo at room temperature as a healthy sweet.

name: Goli Baje
steps: In a bowl, mix all-purpose flour, rice flour, turmeric, and salt.
Add yogurt and mix to form a thick batter.
Add green chilies, ginger paste, and coriander leaves.
Adjust water to get a dropping consistency batter.
Add baking soda just before frying and mix gently.
Heat oil in a deep pan on medium flame.
Drop small portions of batter into hot oil using a spoon.
Fry until golden brown and cooked through.
Turn occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Remove using a slotted spoon.
Drain excess oil on paper towels.
Cool slightly before serving.
Ensure bajes are soft inside and crisp outside.
Repeat with remaining batter.
Serve warm.
howToServe: Serve Goli Baje hot with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup.

name: Mangalore Bonda
steps: Boil and mash potatoes until smooth.
Mix in green peas, green chilies, ginger paste, turmeric, and salt.
Add flour gradually to bind the mixture.
Grease hands lightly and shape mixture into small balls.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Fry the balls until golden brown and crisp.
Turn occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Remove using a slotted spoon.
Drain excess oil on paper towels.
Allow to cool slightly before serving.
Repeat for remaining potato mixture.
Ensure bonda is soft inside and crisp outside.
Garnish with chopped coriander if desired.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Enjoy warm.
howToServe: Serve Mangalore Bonda with coconut chutney or green chutney.

name: Batata Bonda
steps: Boil and mash potatoes until smooth.
Heat a small pan, add mustard seeds, turmeric, green chilies, ginger paste, and asafoetida; sauté briefly.
Mix this tempering into mashed potatoes.
Add salt and combine well.
Prepare a gram flour batter with water, salt, and a pinch of turmeric.
Heat oil in a deep pan on medium flame.
Shape potato mixture into small balls.
Dip each ball into gram flour batter to coat.
Carefully drop coated balls into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crisp.
Turn occasionally for even cooking.
Remove using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Cool slightly before serving.
Ensure crisp exterior and soft interior.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve Batata Bonda hot with coconut or tomato chutney.

name: Mangalore Pakoda
steps: In a bowl, mix gram flour, turmeric, red chili powder, cumin seeds, and salt.
Add chopped onions, green chilies, and curry leaves.
Gradually add water to form a thick batter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Drop spoonfuls of batter into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crisp.
Turn occasionally to ensure even cooking.
Remove using a slotted spoon.
Drain excess oil on paper towels.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Cool slightly before serving.
Ensure crisp texture.
Adjust seasoning if required.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Enjoy warm.
howToServe: Serve Mangalore Pakoda with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup.

name: Vegetable Cutlet
ingredients: 2 cups boiled and mashed mixed vegetables (carrot, beans, peas, potatoes)
steps: Boil and mash vegetables until smooth.
Add chopped onion, green chili, ginger paste, turmeric, and salt; mix well.
Add cornflour or breadcrumbs to bind the mixture.
Divide mixture into small portions and shape into flat patties.
Heat oil in a pan on medium flame for shallow frying.
Fry cutlets on both sides until golden brown and crisp.
Turn carefully to avoid breaking patties.
Remove and drain excess oil on paper towels.
Repeat for remaining portions.
Cool slightly before serving.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Ensure patties are firm and hold shape.
Serve immediately while warm.
Adjust spices as needed.
Enjoy crispy and flavorful cutlets.
howToServe: Serve Vegetable Cutlet hot with tomato ketchup or green chutney.

name: Cabbage & Carrot Pakora
steps: Mix shredded cabbage and grated carrot in a bowl.
Add chopped green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, cumin seeds, and salt.
Add gram flour gradually and mix well.
Add water little by little to form thick batter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Drop spoonfuls of batter into hot oil carefully.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally to ensure even frying.
Remove using slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Avoid overcrowding the pan for uniform cooking.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy crispy, flavorful fritters.
Perfect snack with tea or chutney.
howToServe: Serve Cabbage & Carrot Pakora hot with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup.

name: Onion Pakora / Onion Bhaji
steps: Place sliced onions in a bowl and add chopped green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, ajwain, and salt.
Mix well and add gram flour gradually.
Add water to form a thick, slightly sticky batter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Drop small portions of batter into hot oil using a spoon.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally for even frying.
Remove using slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Avoid overcrowding the pan.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy crispy onion fritters.
Pairs well with tea or chutney.
Perfect for evening snacks or starter.
howToServe: Serve Onion Pakora hot with coconut chutney or mint chutney.

name: Corn & Coconut Fritters
ingredients: 1 cup sweet corn kernels (fresh or boiled)
steps: Mix corn kernels and grated coconut in a bowl.
Add chopped green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, coriander, and salt.
Add gram flour gradually and mix to form thick batter.
Add water if necessary to adjust consistency.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Drop spoonfuls of batter into hot oil carefully.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally to ensure even frying.
Remove using slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Avoid overcrowding the pan.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy sweet-savory fritters with a tropical flavor.
Perfect snack with tea or chutney.
howToServe: Serve Corn & Coconut Fritters hot with coconut chutney or tomato sauce.

name: Mirchi Bonda
steps: Wash and slit green chilies lengthwise; remove seeds if desired.
Prepare stuffing (optional) with boiled potato or onion.
Mix gram flour, turmeric, red chili powder, cumin seeds, and salt in a bowl.
Add water gradually to form medium-thick batter.
Stuff chilies with prepared stuffing if using.
