Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Dip stuffed chilies into batter to coat evenly.
Carefully drop coated chilies into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally for even cooking.
Remove using slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Repeat for remaining chilies.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy spicy, crunchy snack.
howToServe: Serve Chili Bajji hot with coconut chutney or tomato ketchup.

name: Moong Dal Bonda
ingredients: 1 cup moong dal (yellow split gram), soaked 2–3 hours
steps: Drain soaked moong dal and grind with green chilies, ginger, and cumin seeds into coarse paste.
Add chopped coriander and salt; mix well.
Adjust consistency to make thick batter suitable for shaping.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Shape small portions of batter into balls using hands or spoon.
Carefully drop balls into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally for even frying.
Remove using slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy crispy outside and soft inside fritters.
Perfect snack with evening tea.
Can adjust spice level as preferred.
howToServe: Serve Moong Dal Bonda hot with coconut chutney or green chutney.

name: Sweet Banana Fritters
steps: Peel and slice bananas into medium pieces.
Mix gram flour, rice flour, turmeric, cardamom powder, sugar, and salt in a bowl.
Add water gradually to form thick batter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Dip banana slices into the batter to coat evenly.
Carefully drop coated bananas into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally for even frying.
Remove using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Repeat for remaining banana slices.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy sweet, crisp fritters.
Pairs well with tea or coffee.
Optional: sprinkle powdered sugar before serving.
howToServe: Serve Sweet Banana Fritters hot as a snack or dessert.

name: Crispy Cashew & Gram Flour Balls
steps: Mix gram flour, chopped cashews, cardamom powder, sugar, and salt in a bowl.
Add water gradually to form thick batter.
Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame.
Shape small portions of batter into balls using hands or spoon.
Carefully drop balls into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown and crisp on all sides.
Turn occasionally for even frying.
Remove using a slotted spoon and drain excess oil.
Repeat for remaining batter.
Serve immediately for best taste.
Keep warm in a covered dish if needed.
Enjoy nutty, crunchy snacks.
Perfect for festive occasions.
Pairs well with evening tea or coffee.
Can adjust sugar level as desired.
howToServe: Serve Crispy Cashew & Gram Flour Balls hot as an evening snack.

name: Spiced Roasted Chickpeas

name: Mangalorean Chicken Biryani
steps: Wash and soak rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat oil in a pan; sauté curry leaves and sliced onions until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste; sauté 2–3 minutes.
Add tomatoes and green chilies; cook until soft.
Add turmeric, chili, coriander, black pepper powders; sauté 2 minutes.
Add chicken pieces; mix well with masala.
Cook chicken for 10–15 minutes on medium flame until slightly tender.
Pour in coconut milk; simmer 5 minutes.
Adjust salt and spice according to taste.
Boil rice in salted water until 70% cooked; drain and set aside.
Layer half of the rice over the chicken mixture.
Sprinkle half of the mint and coriander leaves over rice.
Layer remaining rice and garnish with remaining mint and coriander.
Cover tightly and cook on low flame (dum) for 15–20 minutes until rice fully cooked.
Turn off flame; let it rest 5–10 minutes before serving.
Gently fluff the biryani and serve hot with raita or pickle.
howToServe: Serve Mangalorean Chicken Biryani hot, accompanied by coconut chutney, raita, or sliced onions for authentic coastal flavor.

name: Chicken Pulao

Add chopped tomatoes and green chilies; cook until tomatoes soften.
Add turmeric, red chili, coriander, black pepper powders; sauté 2–3 minutes.

Cook chicken for 10–12 minutes on medium flame until slightly tender.

In a separate pan, boil rice in salted water until 70% cooked; drain and set aside.
Layer half of the partially cooked rice over the chicken mixture.
Sprinkle half of the mint and coriander leaves.
Layer remaining rice and garnish with remaining mint and coriander.
Cover tightly and cook on low flame (dum) for 15–20 minutes until rice is fully cooked and flavors meld.
Turn off heat and allow pulao to rest for 5–10 minutes.
Gently fluff rice before serving to mix the layers.
Serve hot with coconut chutney or raita on the side.
howToServe: Serve Mangalorean Chicken Pulao warm, accompanied by papad, raita, or a side pickle for authentic flavor.

name: Mutton Biryani
steps: Wash and soak rice for 30 minutes.
Heat oil/ghee in a heavy-bottom pan; fry curry leaves and onions until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until raw smell disappears.
Add chopped tomatoes and green chilies; sauté until tomatoes are soft.
Add turmeric, red chili, coriander, black pepper powders; cook for 2–3 minutes.
Add mutton pieces; mix well with the spice mixture.
Sauté mutton for 10–12 minutes until lightly browned.
Add garam masala, salt, and coconut milk; bring to a boil.
Simmer covered on low-medium flame until mutton is tender (approx. 45–50 minutes).
In a separate pot, boil rice in salted water until 70% cooked; drain and keep aside.
Layer half of the partially cooked rice over the mutton gravy.
Sprinkle half of the mint and coriander leaves over the rice layer.
Add remaining rice and top with remaining mint and coriander leaves.
Cover tightly, cook on low flame (dum) for 20–25 minutes until rice absorbs all flavors.
Turn off heat and allow biryani to rest for 10 minutes.
Gently fluff the biryani before serving to mix rice and mutton layers.
Serve hot with raita, coconut chutney, or a boiled egg on the side.
howToServe: Serve Coastal Mutton Biryani warm with side raita, papad, and optionally a wedge of lemon for added zest.

name: Mutton Pulao
ingredients: 2 cups basmati or sona masoori rice
steps: Wash and soak rice for 30 minutes.
Heat ghee/oil in a heavy-bottomed pan.
Add cumin seeds and curry leaves; sauté for a few seconds.
Add sliced onions; fry until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook until raw aroma disappears.
Add green chilies, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and black pepper; sauté for 1–2 minutes.
Add mutton pieces and salt; mix well with the spice mixture.
Sauté mutton for 10–12 minutes until lightly browned.
Add coconut milk and water; bring to a boil.
Cover and simmer on low flame until mutton is tender (approx. 45–50 minutes).
Once mutton is cooked, check seasoning and adjust salt/spices.
Drain the soaked rice and add it to the mutton gravy; stir gently.
Cover and cook on low flame until rice is cooked and all liquid is absorbed (approx. 15–20 minutes).
Turn off heat and let pulao rest for 5–10 minutes.
Garnish with chopped coriander and mint leaves before serving.
Serve hot, accompanied by raita or a light salad.
Optionally, drizzle some ghee on top before serving for extra aroma.
howToServe: Serve Mutton Pulao hot with cucumber raita, fried onions, and papad. Can also accompany a simple pickle for added flavor.

name: Fish Biryani
ingredients: 500g fish (Pomfret or any firm coastal fish), cleaned and cut into steaks
Fresh coriander and mint leaves for garnish
steps: Wash and soak the rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat ghee or oil in a heavy-bottomed pan.
Add cumin seeds, fennel seeds, and curry leaves; sauté briefly.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté until raw aroma disappears.
Add tomatoes, turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt; cook until tomatoes soften.
Mix yogurt and coconut milk into the masala; cook for 2–3 minutes.
Gently add fish pieces to the masala; coat them well.
Cook fish on low flame for 5–7 minutes until partially done; avoid breaking the fish.
Drain rice and add it gently over the fish layer.
Add water and a little salt; bring to a boil.
Cover and cook on very low flame (dum style) until rice is cooked and liquid is absorbed (approx. 15–20 minutes).
Turn off the heat and let biryani rest for 5–10 minutes.
Squeeze lemon juice over the biryani and gently fluff the rice with a fork.
Garnish with chopped coriander and mint leaves before serving.
Serve hot with coconut raita or pickle for a coastal touch.
howToServe: Serve Fish Biryani hot, accompanied by coconut raita, salad, and papad. Perfect for festive coastal meals or weekend lunches.

Heat coconut oil in a heavy pan; add cumin seeds, cloves, cinnamon, cardamom, and curry leaves; sauté until aromatic.
Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
Add mutton pieces and cook on medium flame for 10–12 minutes until browned and water evaporates.
Add 1 1/2 cups water, cover, and simmer until mutton is tender and cooked through.
Drain the soaked rice and cook it partially (about 70% done) in boiling water with a pinch of salt; drain excess water.
Layer the partially cooked rice over the cooked mutton in the pan.
Sprinkle fresh coriander, mint leaves, and lemon juice over the rice.
Cover tightly with a lid and cook on low flame (dum) for 15–20 minutes.
Turn off heat and let it rest for 5 minutes before opening.
Gently mix rice and mutton to combine.
Check seasoning and adjust if necessary.
Serve hot with pickle, raita, or salad.
howToServe: Serve Mutton Sukka Pulao hot, garnished with fresh coriander and mint leaves, alongside coconut chutney, raita, or spicy pickle.

name: Spicy Fish Masala Biryani
ingredients: 500g firm fish (Pomfret or Kingfish), cleaned and cut into pieces
Fresh coriander and mint leaves for garnish
steps: Rinse and soak basmati rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat coconut oil in a heavy pan; add cumin seeds, cloves, cinnamon, cardamom, and curry leaves; sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and sauté until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
Add fish pieces and gently coat with the masala; cook on medium flame for 5–6 minutes.
Add a little water (1/4 cup) and cook covered until fish is tender and infused with spices.
Drain the soaked rice and cook it partially (about 70% done) in boiling water with a pinch of salt; drain excess water.
Layer the partially cooked rice over the cooked fish in the pan.
Sprinkle fresh coriander, mint leaves, and lemon juice over the rice.
Optional: add a dollop of yogurt to enhance creaminess.
Cover tightly with a lid and cook on low flame (dum) for 15–20 minutes.
Turn off heat and let it rest for 5 minutes before opening.
Gently mix rice and fish masala to combine without breaking the fish pieces.
Check seasoning and adjust if necessary.
howToServe: Serve Spicy Fish Masala Biryani hot, garnished with fresh coriander and mint leaves, with lemon wedges, coconut chutney, or raita.

name: Prawn Pepper Biryani
ingredients: Fresh coriander and mint leaves for garnish
steps: Rinse and soak basmati rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan; add cumin seeds, cloves, cinnamon, cardamom, and curry leaves; sauté until aromatic.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add turmeric, black pepper, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
Add prawns and coat gently with the masala; cook on medium flame for 4–5 minutes until prawns start turning pink.
Add a little water (1/4 cup) and cook covered for another 2–3 minutes.
Drain soaked rice and cook it partially (70% done) in boiling salted water; drain excess water.
Layer the partially cooked rice over the cooked prawns.
Sprinkle fresh coriander, mint leaves, and lemon juice over the rice.
Optional: add a spoon of yogurt for mild creaminess.
Cover tightly and cook on low flame (dum) for 15–20 minutes.
Turn off heat and let it rest for 5 minutes before opening.
Gently fluff the rice with a fork, mixing lightly with the prawn masala.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or pepper as needed.
howToServe: Serve Prawn Pepper Biryani hot, garnished with fresh coriander and mint leaves, alongside coconut chutney, raita, or a wedge of lemon.

name: Crab Masala Pulao
ingredients: Fresh coriander and mint leaves for garnish
steps: Rinse and soak basmati rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat ghee in a pan; add cumin seeds, cloves, cinnamon, cardamom, and curry leaves; sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
Add crab pieces and coat gently with the masala; cook for 5–6 minutes.
Add 1/4 cup water, cover, and simmer for another 5 minutes.
Drain soaked rice and cook partially (70% done) in boiling salted water; drain excess water.
Layer partially cooked rice over the crab masala.
Sprinkle fresh coriander, mint leaves, and lemon juice over the rice.
Optional: add a spoon of yogurt for mild creaminess.
Cover tightly and cook on low flame (dum) for 15–20 minutes.
Turn off heat and let it rest for 5 minutes before opening.
Gently fluff the rice with a fork, mixing lightly with the crab masala.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or spices as needed.
howToServe: Serve Crab Masala Pulao hot, garnished with fresh coriander and mint leaves, with coconut chutney, raita, or a wedge of lemon on the side.

name: Chicken Coconut Pulao
ingredients: Fresh coriander and mint leaves for garnish
steps: Rinse and soak basmati rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat coconut oil or ghee in a pan; add cumin seeds, cloves, cinnamon, cardamom, and curry leaves; sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
Add chicken pieces and coat gently with the masala; cook for 8–10 minutes until chicken is partially cooked.
Add grated coconut and mix thoroughly.
Add water or chicken stock; bring to a boil.
Drain soaked rice and add it to the chicken mixture; mix gently.
Reduce flame, cover, and cook on low heat for 15–20 minutes until rice is fully cooked and liquid is absorbed.
Turn off heat and let it rest for 5 minutes.
Gently fluff the rice with a fork, mixing lightly with the chicken.
Sprinkle fresh coriander and mint leaves over the pulao.
Add lemon juice and give a gentle stir before serving.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or spices if needed.
howToServe: Serve Chicken Coconut Pulao hot with raita, coconut chutney, or a side salad for a complete coastal meal.

name: Mutton Coconut Pulao
ingredients: Fresh coriander and mint leaves for garnish
steps: Rinse and soak basmati rice for 20–30 minutes.
Heat coconut oil or ghee in a pan; add cumin seeds, cloves, cinnamon, cardamom, and curry leaves; sauté until fragrant.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt; mix well.
Add mutton pieces and coat gently with the masala; cook for 15–20 minutes until partially cooked.
Add grated coconut and mix thoroughly.
Add water or mutton stock; bring to a boil.
Drain soaked rice and add it to the mutton mixture; mix gently.
Reduce flame, cover, and cook on low heat for 20–25 minutes until rice is fully cooked and liquid is absorbed.
Turn off heat and let it rest for 5–10 minutes.
Gently fluff the rice with a fork, mixing lightly with the mutton.
Sprinkle fresh coriander and mint leaves over the pulao.
Add lemon juice and give a gentle stir before serving.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or spices if needed.
howToServe: Serve Mutton Coconut Pulao hot with raita, coconut chutney, or a fresh salad for a complete coastal meal.

name: Chicken Cutlet
steps: Boil the chicken until tender and shred it finely.
Boil potatoes until soft, peel, and mash them without lumps.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry until fragrant.
Mix in green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, and garam masala.
Stir well and add shredded chicken, sautéing for a few minutes.
Turn off heat and let the chicken mixture cool slightly.
In a bowl, combine mashed potatoes with the chicken mixture.
Add salt and chopped coriander leaves, mixing thoroughly.
Take small portions of the mixture and shape them into oval or round cutlets.
Dip each cutlet into the beaten egg mixture.
Roll the cutlets in bread crumbs until evenly coated.
Heat oil in a shallow pan for frying.
Place cutlets carefully in the hot oil and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Remove cutlets and drain excess oil on a paper towel.
Ensure the cutlets are crispy on the outside and soft inside.
Repeat the process for all shaped cutlets.
Cool slightly before serving to avoid breaking apart.
howToServe: Serve hot with ketchup, green chutney, or as a side with evening tea.

name: Mutton Cutlet
steps: Boil minced mutton until cooked and drain excess water.
Mash the boiled mutton slightly and keep aside.
Boil potatoes until soft, peel, and mash them smoothly.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry until fragrant.
Mix in green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, and garam masala.
Add the cooked mutton mince and sauté until dry.
Turn off heat and allow mixture to cool.
In a bowl, combine mashed potatoes with spiced mutton mixture.
Add salt and chopped coriander leaves, mixing thoroughly.
Take small portions of the mixture and shape into cutlets.
Dip each cutlet into the beaten egg mixture.
Roll the cutlets in bread crumbs for an even coating.
Heat oil in a shallow pan for frying.
Place cutlets carefully and fry until golden brown on both sides.
Remove and drain excess oil on a paper towel.
Ensure they are crispy outside and soft inside before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney, ketchup, or alongside evening tea.

name: Fish Cutlet
steps: Boil or steam fish fillets until cooked.
Remove skin and bones, shred finely.
Boil potatoes until soft and mash them without lumps.
Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry until fragrant.
Mix in green chilies, turmeric, red chili powder, and pepper powder.
Add shredded fish and sauté well until mixture turns dry.
Turn off heat and allow mixture to cool slightly.
Combine mashed potatoes with the fish mixture.
Add salt and chopped coriander leaves, mix thoroughly.
Shape mixture into round or oval cutlets.
Dip each cutlet in beaten egg.
Roll in bread crumbs to coat evenly.
Heat oil in a shallow pan for frying.
Fry cutlets on both sides until golden brown and crisp.
Drain excess oil on paper towels before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, ketchup, or spicy green chutney.

name: Chicken Puff (Bakery Style)
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, sauté until fragrant.
Add shredded chicken and mix well.
Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt.
Cook till the filling becomes dry and aromatic.
Turn off heat and stir in coriander leaves.
Allow mixture to cool completely.
Preheat oven to 200°C (392°F).
Roll out puff pastry sheets and cut into squares.
Place 2 tbsp chicken filling in the center of each pastry.
Fold pastry into triangles or rectangles and seal edges.
Press edges with a fork for a bakery-style look.
Brush tops with beaten egg for shine.
Arrange on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.
Bake at 200°C for 20–25 minutes until golden and crispy.
Remove from oven and let them cool slightly before serving.
howToServe: Serve warm as a tea-time snack with ketchup or spicy sauce.

name: Mutton Puff
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry until raw smell disappears.
Add minced mutton and cook until browned.
Mix in turmeric, red chili powder, garam masala, and salt.
Cook till mutton is well cooked and mixture is dry.
Turn off heat and add coriander leaves.
Let the mixture cool completely before stuffing.
Preheat oven to 200°C (392°F).
Roll out puff pastry sheets and cut into squares or rectangles.
Spoon 2 tbsp mutton filling into each pastry piece.
Fold and seal edges properly with a fork.
Brush top of each pastry with beaten egg for golden finish.
Arrange on a baking tray lined with parchment paper.
Bake for 20–25 minutes until crisp and golden brown.
Remove from oven and rest for 2 minutes before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney, ketchup, or spicy sauce as a bakery-style snack.

name: Chicken Roll (Stuffed in Paratha)
steps: Mix flour, salt, oil, and water to knead a soft dough; rest for 30 minutes.
Divide dough into equal balls and roll into thin parathas.
Cook each paratha lightly on a tawa with little oil, keep aside.
Heat oil in a pan, sauté onions until soft.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry until raw smell disappears.
Add chicken pieces and cook until they turn white.
Sprinkle chili powder, turmeric, salt, and garam masala.
Mix well, then add tomatoes and capsicum.
Cook until chicken is fully done and masala is dry.
Add chopped coriander and turn off the heat.
Take one paratha and spread a thin layer of green chutney.
Add mayonnaise over chutney for creaminess.
Place chicken masala in the center of the paratha.
Fold sides and roll tightly into a wrap shape.
Heat roll on tawa for a crispy outer layer.
Serve hot with ketchup or chutney.
howToServe: Serve hot with green chutney or ketchup, wrapped in butter paper for authentic street-style taste.

name: Mutton Roll
steps: Prepare dough with flour, salt, and oil; rest 30 minutes.
Roll into thin parathas and cook lightly with oil on a hot tawa.
Heat oil in pan, add onions and sauté until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry well.
Add minced mutton and cook until it turns brown.
Add chili powder, turmeric, salt, cumin powder, and garam masala.
Stir and cook until masala blends with meat.
Add tomatoes and cook until soft and dry.
Mix chopped coriander and green chili.
Take one paratha and spread mint chutney.
Layer mayonnaise over chutney.
Fill with cooked mutton masala.
Roll paratha tightly around stuffing.
Shallow fry rolls on tawa until crispy.
Serve hot with onion salad.
howToServe: Best enjoyed hot with mint chutney and onion salad, wrapped for a street-food style presentation.

name: Fish Roll
steps: Make dough with flour, salt, and water; rest for 30 minutes.
Roll into thin parathas and half-cook them on a tawa.
Heat oil in a pan and fry onions until soft.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté.
Add tomatoes, cook until mushy.
Add shredded fish pieces to pan.
Sprinkle chili powder, turmeric, pepper, and salt.
Mix well until masala is dry.
Squeeze lemon juice and add chopped coriander.
Take a paratha and spread chutney over it.
Add a thin layer of mayonnaise.
Fill fish masala in the center.
Fold sides and roll tightly.
Toast roll lightly on tawa with oil until crisp.
Serve hot with sauce or chutney.
howToServe: Serve hot with green chutney or ketchup, best eaten fresh for crispy texture.

name: Chicken Sandwich (Local Bakery Style)
steps: Boil chicken until tender, shred into small pieces.
Mix shredded chicken with onion, tomato, and green chili.
Add mayonnaise, pepper, chili flakes, and salt.
Stir until mixture is creamy and consistent.
Take bread slices and apply butter on one side.
Spread chicken mixture evenly on bread.
Add lettuce and cucumber slices for crunch.
Cover with another bread slice.
Press lightly and cut edges if needed.
Cut sandwich diagonally for serving.
Toast lightly on a pan for crispy edges (optional).
Serve hot with ketchup.
Can be wrapped in butter paper for storage.
Tastes similar to local bakery sandwiches.
Best served fresh.
howToServe: Serve warm or at room temperature with ketchup, wrapped in butter paper for an authentic bakery-style touch.

name: Mutton Sandwich
steps: Heat oil in a pan and fry onion until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté.
Add minced mutton and cook until brown.
Add chili powder, turmeric, salt, and garam masala.
Mix in chopped tomatoes and cook until dry.
Turn off heat and let filling cool slightly.
Spread butter on bread slices.
Place mutton filling on bread.
Add lettuce leaves and mayonnaise.
Cover with another bread slice.
Press lightly and cut edges neatly.
Toast sandwich on a pan until crispy (optional).
Cut diagonally before serving.
Wrap in butter paper for bakery style look.
Serve hot with green chutney or ketchup.
howToServe: Best served hot with green chutney or ketchup, wrapped in butter paper for bakery-style presentation.

name: Tuna Sandwich
steps: Take canned tuna in a bowl and shred it lightly with a fork.
Add mayonnaise, chopped onion, green chili, black pepper, and salt.
Mix well until everything is combined.
Butter the bread slices and lightly toast them if preferred.
Place lettuce leaves on one slice.
Spread a generous portion of the tuna mixture on top.
Cover with another slice of bread.
Cut diagonally into halves or quarters.
Repeat for remaining bread slices.
Serve immediately with ketchup or sauce of choice.
howToServe: Serve fresh with ketchup or mayonnaise-based dip.

name: Chicken Bun
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili, fry till aromatic.
Mix in turmeric, chili powder, and garam masala.
Add shredded chicken and sauté for 2–3 minutes.
Sprinkle salt and mix well.
Turn off heat and add chopped coriander leaves.
Slice buns horizontally without cutting fully.
Stuff the prepared chicken masala inside the buns.
Heat a tawa with butter and lightly toast the stuffed buns.
Serve warm with tea or ketchup.
howToServe: Best enjoyed hot with tea or tomato ketchup.

name: Mutton Bun
steps: Heat oil in a pan and fry onions till light brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili, sauté well.
Add minced mutton and cook till water dries up.
Sprinkle turmeric, chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala.
Add salt and cook till masala blends well.
Garnish with coriander leaves.
Slice buns horizontally and stuff with mutton filling.
Toast lightly on a tawa with butter for flavor.
Serve hot with chutney or sauce.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney or spicy sauce.

name: Chicken Samosa
steps: Heat oil in a pan and fry onions till golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili, sauté well.
Mix in turmeric, chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala.
Add shredded chicken and mix thoroughly.
Sprinkle salt and cook for 2 minutes.
Add coriander leaves and turn off the heat.
Take samosa sheets and place 1 tbsp filling inside.
Fold into triangular samosas and seal edges with flour paste.
Heat oil for deep frying.
Fry samosas until golden and crispy.
Drain excess oil on paper towels.
Serve hot with mint chutney or ketchup.
howToServe: Serve crispy with mint chutney or tomato ketchup.

name: Mutton Samosa
steps: Heat oil in a pan and fry chopped onions until brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chili, sauté till aromatic.
Add minced mutton and cook till it changes color.
Mix in turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, and garam masala.
Sprinkle salt and cook until dry.
Add coriander leaves and mix well.
Cool the filling slightly before stuffing.
Take samosa sheets and place 1 tbsp filling inside.
Fold into triangular shape and seal with flour paste.
Heat oil and deep fry until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels to remove excess oil.
Serve hot with sauce or chutney.
howToServe: Best enjoyed hot with mint chutney or spicy sauce.

name: Fish Samosa
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, fry well.
Add shredded fish, cumin, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt.
Cook until mixture turns dry.
Add coriander leaves and allow filling to cool.
Place 1 tbsp of filling in each samosa sheet.
Fold into triangular samosas and seal with flour paste.
Deep fry in hot oil until golden brown.
Drain excess oil on paper towel.
Serve hot with mint chutney or ketchup.
howToServe: Best enjoyed hot with mint chutney or ketchup.

name: Chicken Croquette
steps: Heat oil in a pan and fry onions until soft.
Add ginger-garlic paste, green chilies, and sauté well.
Mix in chicken, mashed potatoes, garam masala, pepper, chili flakes, and salt.
Shape mixture into croquettes (cylindrical or oval).
Dip croquettes in beaten egg.
Roll in breadcrumbs until coated.
Heat oil in a pan and deep fry until golden brown.
Drain excess oil on paper towel.
Serve hot with ketchup or chutney.
howToServe: Serve warm with ketchup, chutney, or as a tea-time snack.

name: Mutton Croquette
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and green chilies, fry well.
Mix in minced mutton, spices, and salt, cook until dry.
Combine with mashed potatoes and mix evenly.
Shape mixture into croquettes.
Dip in beaten egg and roll in breadcrumbs.
Deep fry in hot oil until golden brown.
Drain excess oil on tissue paper.
Serve hot with mint chutney or ketchup.
howToServe: Perfect as an evening snack with chutney or sauce.

name: Fish Croquette
steps: Heat oil in a pan and sauté onions until soft.
Add ginger-garlic paste, green chilies, and sauté well.
Add fish, pepper, garam masala, and salt, mix well.
Combine mixture with mashed potatoes.
Shape into croquettes and dip in beaten egg.
Roll croquettes in breadcrumbs.
Deep fry until golden and crispy.
Drain excess oil on paper towel.
Serve hot with ketchup or chutney.
howToServe: Serve with ketchup, mayonnaise, or chutney.

name: Meat Bun (Keema Bun)
steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm milk, let it rise for 10 minutes.
Mix with flour, butter, and salt to form dough.
Knead well until smooth and cover for 1–2 hours to rise.
Meanwhile, prepare filling: sauté onions, chilies, and ginger-garlic paste in oil.
Add minced meat, coriander powder, garam masala, and salt.
Cook until mixture is dry and aromatic, then cool.
Punch down dough and divide into balls.
Flatten each ball, stuff with meat filling, and seal.
Place stuffed buns on a tray, brush with egg wash.
Bake at 180°C until golden brown.
Cool slightly before serving.
howToServe: Enjoy warm as a bakery-style snack or evening treat.

name: Chicken Reshmi Kebab
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken cubes.
In a bowl, mix curd, cream, cashew paste, ginger-garlic paste, green chilies, lemon juice, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt.
Coat chicken cubes with this creamy marinade.
Refrigerate for at least 2–3 hours for best results.
Preheat grill or oven to 220°C.
Thread chicken cubes onto skewers.
Grill for 15–20 minutes, basting with butter occasionally.
Turn skewers to cook evenly on all sides.
Remove when chicken is juicy, tender, and slightly charred.
Sprinkle with chaat masala before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney, onion rings, and lemon wedges.

name: Chicken Tikka
steps: Wash and clean chicken pieces thoroughly.
In a mixing bowl, whisk curd until smooth.
Add ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, cumin powder, and garam masala.
Mix well to form a thick marinade.
Add lemon juice, salt, and oil.
Coat chicken cubes evenly with this marinade.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 2–3 hours.
Preheat oven or tandoor at 220°C.
Skewer marinated chicken pieces on sticks.
Place skewers on a greased baking tray.
Bake for 15 minutes, turning halfway.
Baste with butter and cook until slightly charred.
Alternatively, grill on charcoal for smoky flavor.
Ensure chicken is cooked fully inside.
Remove and rest for 2 minutes before serving.
Serve hot with mint chutney and onion rings.
howToServe: Serve with mint chutney, lemon wedges, and onion slices.

name: Chicken Malai Tikka
steps: Clean and pat dry chicken pieces.
In a mixing bowl, add cream, curd, and grated cheese.
Whisk until smooth and creamy.
Add ginger-garlic paste, chopped chilies, lemon juice, and spices.
Mix in cornflour for binding.
Add salt and combine into a thick marinade.
Coat chicken cubes evenly with this mixture.
Refrigerate for 2–3 hours for best results.
Preheat oven to 200°C or prepare grill.
Arrange chicken cubes on skewers.
Place them on greased baking tray.
Bake for 20 minutes, turning once halfway.
Brush with butter and grill until golden.
Ensure chicken remains juicy and soft.
Remove and rest for 2 minutes.
Serve hot with green chutney.
howToServe: Serve with mint chutney or mayonnaise dip for a creamy taste.

name: Chicken Kebab (South Indian)
steps: Wash and drain minced chicken.
In a blender, add onion, green chilies, coriander, and mint.
Grind into a coarse paste.
Mix this paste with minced chicken.
Add ginger-garlic paste, garam masala, chili powder, and fennel powder.
Break in an egg for binding.
Add bread crumbs to hold mixture together.
Season with salt and mix thoroughly.
Shape into oval or round kebabs.
Heat oil in a tawa on medium flame.
Place kebabs and cook slowly.
Flip once browned on one side.
Cook until golden and fully cooked inside.
Remove and drain on tissue paper.
Serve hot with onion rings and chutney.
howToServe: Serve with onion slices, lemon wedges, and mint chutney.

name: Chicken 65
steps: Clean and cut chicken into small cubes.
In a mixing bowl, add cornflour, rice flour, and egg.
Add ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, and garam masala.
Mix in curd and lemon juice.
Season with salt.
Coat chicken pieces evenly with marinade.
Rest for at least 1 hour.
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Drop chicken pieces in batches.
Fry until golden brown and crisp.
Remove onto tissue paper to absorb oil.
In another pan, heat 1 tsp oil.
Add curry leaves and slit green chilies.
Toss fried chicken in this tempering.
Mix well to coat chicken.
Serve hot as a spicy starter.
howToServe: Serve hot with onion rings and lemon wedges.

name: Mutton Kebab
steps: Wash and drain minced mutton well.
Squeeze out any excess water for firm kebabs.
In a blender, add onion, green chilies, coriander, and mint.
Pulse into a coarse paste without adding water.
Mix this paste into the minced mutton.
Add ginger-garlic paste, garam masala, chili powder, cumin powder, and fennel powder.
Roast gram flour lightly and add to the mixture.
Break in one egg for binding.
Add salt and knead mixture with hands.
Keep mixture refrigerated for 30 minutes.
Divide mixture into equal portions.
Shape into oval or cylindrical kebabs.
Heat oil in a tawa on medium flame.
Place kebabs gently and cook slowly.
Flip once golden on one side.
Cook evenly until firm and browned outside.
Drain on tissue paper to remove excess oil.
Garnish with onion rings and lemon wedges.
Serve hot with green chutney.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney, onion slices, and lemon wedges.

name: Fish Tikka
steps: Clean and cut fish into medium cubes.
Pat fish dry to avoid watery marinade.
In a mixing bowl, whisk curd until smooth.
Add ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, chili powder, cumin, and garam masala.
Mix into a thick marinade.
Add lemon juice, oil, and salt.
Coat fish pieces evenly with marinade.
Refrigerate for 1–2 hours.
Preheat oven or tandoor to 220°C.
Thread fish cubes onto skewers.
Place skewers on greased baking tray.
Bake for 12–15 minutes, turning once.
Baste with butter midway for smoky flavor.
Ensure fish is cooked but soft inside.
Remove from oven and rest briefly.
Garnish with lemon wedges.
Sprinkle chaat masala before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with onion rings, mint chutney, and lemon wedges.

name: Fish Kebab
ingredients: 500g boneless fish fillet (minced or finely chopped)
steps: Wash and dry fish fillets thoroughly.
Mince fish finely or chop into tiny pieces.
In a bowl, mix fish with onion and green chilies.
Add coriander, mint leaves, and ginger-garlic paste.
Sprinkle cumin powder, garam masala, and chili powder.
Break in one egg for binding.
Add bread crumbs gradually to form firm mixture.
Season with salt and mix thoroughly.
Cover and refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Shape mixture into patties or oval kebabs.
Heat oil in a tawa on medium flame.
Shallow fry kebabs until golden brown.
Flip and cook evenly on both sides.
Remove onto tissue paper.
Serve immediately with chutney.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney and onion slices.

name: Prawn Ghee Roast (starter portion)
steps: Wash and clean prawns thoroughly.
Pat them dry to remove moisture.
Soak dry red chilies in warm water for 15 minutes.
Grind with coriander, cumin, pepper, and fenugreek into smooth paste.
Mix curd, lemon juice, salt, and half of the paste.
Marinate prawns in this mixture for 30 minutes.
Heat ghee in a pan on medium flame.
Add curry leaves and sauté until fragrant.
Add remaining masala paste and fry until ghee separates.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté briefly.
Add marinated prawns into pan.
Cook on high heat for 2–3 minutes.
Lower flame and cook until prawns turn pink.
Add jaggery for mild sweetness.
Roast until prawns are dry and coated in masala.
Adjust salt if required.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot as a dry starter with onion slices and lemon wedges.

name: Prawn Tikka
steps: Clean and devein prawns thoroughly.
Pat prawns dry with a cloth.
In a bowl, whisk curd until smooth.
Add ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, garam masala, and cumin powder.
Mix in lemon juice, oil, and salt.
Coat prawns evenly with marinade.
Refrigerate for 30–45 minutes.
Preheat oven to 220°C or heat grill.
Thread prawns onto skewers.
Place skewers on greased tray.
Bake for 10–12 minutes, turning once.
Baste with butter halfway through.
Cook until prawns curl and turn pink.
Remove and rest for 2 minutes.
Garnish with lemon wedges.
Sprinkle chaat masala before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney and onion slices.

name: Squid Chilli Fry (starter style)
steps: Clean and cut squid into rings.
Pat dry to remove excess moisture.
Make a batter using cornflour, flour, egg, salt, and pepper.
Dip squid rings in batter and coat well.
Heat oil and deep fry until golden and crisp.
Remove and set aside on tissue paper.
In another pan, heat 1 tbsp oil.
Add sliced onion, capsicum, and green chilies.
Stir-fry on high heat for 2 minutes.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté briefly.
Mix in soy sauce, chili sauce, and vinegar.
Add fried squid rings and toss well.
Adjust seasoning if required.
Sprinkle pepper powder for extra spice.
Cook until squid absorbs sauces.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot as a spicy starter with onion rings and lemon wedges.

name: Crab Pepper Fry
steps: Clean and crack crab pieces.
Heat oil in a pan and add curry leaves.
Sauté sliced onion and green chilies until soft.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook till fragrant.
Sprinkle turmeric, coriander, and garam masala.
Add crab pieces and mix well.
Season with salt.
Cover and cook on medium flame.
Crab will release water; cook until dry.
Add freshly ground pepper generously.
Stir-fry until crab is coated with spices.
Adjust seasoning if needed.
Cook until crab shells turn red and meat is tender.
Garnish with curry leaves.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with onion slices and lemon wedges.

name: Chicken Lollipop (starter)
steps: Clean chicken lollipops and pat dry.
Prepare marinade with cornflour, flour, egg, salt, chili powder, pepper, and ginger-garlic paste.
Coat chicken lollipops evenly in marinade.
Rest for 30 minutes.
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Fry chicken lollipops in batches until golden and crisp.
Remove onto tissue paper to drain excess oil.
In another pan, heat 1 tbsp oil.
Add soy sauce, chili sauce, and tomato ketchup.
Toss fried lollipops in the sauce mixture.
Ensure they are well coated.
Cook for 2 minutes until glossy.
Adjust spice level as per taste.
Sprinkle pepper powder before serving.
Garnish with spring onions.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with schezwan chutney or garlic sauce.

name: Chicken Chilli (dry starter)
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken pieces.
Make a marinade using cornflour, flour, egg, salt, and pepper.
Coat chicken pieces and keep aside for 20 minutes.
Deep fry until golden and set aside.
Heat oil in a wok and add ginger-garlic paste.
Sauté onion, capsicum, and green chilies on high flame.
Add soy sauce, chili sauce, vinegar, and ketchup.
Stir well until sauce thickens slightly.
Add fried chicken cubes.
Toss well to coat with sauce.
Add pepper powder for spice.
Cook for 2–3 minutes on high heat.
Adjust seasoning if required.
Garnish with spring onions.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with schezwan chutney or as a dry Indo-Chinese starter.

name: Mutton Pepper Fry (starter portion)
steps: Wash and clean mutton pieces.
Pressure cook mutton with salt, turmeric, and little water until tender.
Heat oil in a pan and add curry leaves.
Sauté sliced onion and green chilies until golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook till raw smell disappears.
Sprinkle coriander powder and garam masala.
Add boiled mutton pieces with stock.
Fry on medium flame until stock reduces.
Add freshly ground black pepper generously.
Cook until oil separates and mutton is well coated.
Adjust salt if required.
Fry until dry and aromatic.
Garnish with curry leaves.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot as a spicy dry starter with onion and lemon wedges.

name: Chicken Sholay Kebab
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken strips.
Prepare a marinade with curd, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, garam masala, lemon juice, and salt.
Add cornflour for coating and mix well.
Marinate chicken for 1–2 hours.
Heat oil in a pan.
Shallow fry chicken strips until golden and crispy.
Turn occasionally for even cooking.
Remove onto paper towels to drain excess oil.
Sprinkle chaat masala before serving.
Garnish with coriander leaves.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney and lemon wedges.

name: Mutton Seekh Kebab
steps: Wash and drain minced mutton thoroughly.
In a bowl, mix mutton with onion, green chilies, coriander, and ginger-garlic paste.
Add garam masala, cumin powder, chili powder, and salt.
Mix in roasted gram flour and egg for binding.
Knead mixture well until combined.
Refrigerate for 30 minutes.
Divide mixture into equal portions.
Shape around skewers into cylindrical kebabs.
Preheat grill or oven to 220°C.
Cook kebabs, basting with oil occasionally.
Grill until browned and cooked through.
Remove from skewers carefully.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with onion slices, green chutney, and lemon wedges.

name: Chicken Tangdi Kebab (drumstick style)
steps: Clean and pat dry chicken drumsticks.
Make slits on drumsticks for better marinade absorption.
Prepare marinade with curd, ginger-garlic paste, chili powder, turmeric, garam masala, lemon juice, oil, and salt.
Coat drumsticks well with marinade.
Refrigerate for at least 2 hours.
Preheat oven or tandoor to 200°C.
Place drumsticks on a baking tray.
Bake for 25–30 minutes, turning once.
Baste with butter halfway through cooking.
Cook until drumsticks are juicy and well roasted.
Remove and rest for 5 minutes.
Garnish with coriander leaves.
howToServe: Serve hot with mint chutney and onion rings.

name: Chicken Hariyali Kebab
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken cubes.
Grind coriander, mint leaves, and green chilies into a smooth paste.
Mix paste with curd, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, cumin powder, garam masala, and salt.
Coat chicken pieces with marinade.
Refrigerate for 1–2 hours.
Preheat grill or oven to 220°C.
Thread chicken cubes onto skewers.
Grill for 12–15 minutes, turning once.
Baste with butter halfway through cooking.
Remove when chicken is tender and slightly charred.
Sprinkle chaat masala before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with onion rings, mint chutney, and lemon wedges.

name: Prawn Tempura (fusion starter)
steps: Clean and devein prawns, keeping tails intact.
Pat prawns dry with a cloth.
In a bowl, mix flour, cornflour, and salt.
Add beaten egg and chilled soda water gradually.
Mix lightly (do not overmix; batter should be lumpy).
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Dip prawns into batter, holding by tail.
Drop gently into hot oil.
Fry on medium-high heat until golden and crisp.
Remove onto paper towels to drain excess oil.
Do not overcrowd pan while frying.
Repeat with remaining prawns.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve crispy with soy sauce, spicy mayo, or mint chutney for fusion style.

name: Chicken Fry (Mangalore Style)
steps: Wash and clean chicken pieces thoroughly, pat dry.
Marinate chicken with turmeric powder, chili powder, coriander powder, cumin powder, garam masala, ginger-garlic paste, curd, lemon juice, and salt.
Mix well so the spices coat the chicken evenly.
Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours for better flavor absorption.
Heat coconut oil in a heavy-bottomed pan.
Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
Add dried red chilies and curry leaves, sauté until aromatic.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add marinated chicken pieces to the pan.
Cook on high flame for 2–3 minutes while stirring to seal the juices.
Lower the flame, cover, and cook until chicken is half done.
Stir occasionally to avoid sticking and burning.
Uncover and cook until the chicken releases oil and becomes semi-dry.
Increase the flame slightly to roast the chicken with onions and spices.
Fry until the chicken turns golden and slightly crispy on the edges.
Add more curry leaves for aroma and mix gently.
Taste and adjust salt or spice if required.
Once dry and well roasted, turn off the flame.
Let it rest for 2 minutes before serving.
howToServe: Serve hot with neer dosa, boiled rice, or as a spicy starter with lemon wedges.

name: Chicken Rava Fry
steps: Wash and clean chicken pieces thoroughly and pat dry.
Marinate chicken with turmeric, chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, and salt.
Let the chicken rest in the refrigerator for 1–2 hours.
Spread semolina on a plate.
Roll each marinated chicken piece in semolina to coat evenly.
Heat coconut oil in a heavy pan or wok.
Add curry leaves and green chilies, sauté for a few seconds.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Gently add semolina-coated chicken pieces to the pan.
Fry on medium flame for 5–7 minutes, turning occasionally.
Cover the pan and cook for 10 minutes to ensure chicken cooks through.
Remove the lid and increase flame slightly to crisp the outer coating.
Toss carefully to avoid breaking the semolina crust.
Cook until the chicken is golden brown and slightly crispy.
Adjust salt and sprinkle fresh coriander leaves.
Remove from pan and drain excess oil if needed.
Serve immediately hot for best taste.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, lemon wedges, or as a spicy starter.

name: Chicken Masala Fry
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken pieces thoroughly.
In a large bowl, mix chicken with ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, garam masala, black pepper, lemon juice, and salt.
Marinate for at least 1–2 hours in the refrigerator.
Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pan on medium flame.
Add curry leaves and green chilies, sauté for a few seconds.
Add sliced onions and fry until translucent and slightly browned.
Add marinated chicken pieces to the pan.
Stir-fry on medium-high flame for 5–7 minutes.
Reduce flame, cover, and cook for 10–12 minutes to allow chicken to cook thoroughly.
Uncover and increase flame slightly to roast chicken pieces evenly.
Toss occasionally to ensure all pieces are coated with spices.
Cook until chicken is dry and aromatic, with a slightly crispy exterior.
Check for seasoning and adjust salt if required.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Remove from pan and let it rest for 2–3 minutes.
Serve hot as a starter or side dish.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, onion rings, or green chutney.

name: Chicken Ghee Fry
steps: Wash chicken pieces and pat dry thoroughly.
Marinate chicken with ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper, garam masala, lemon juice, and salt.
Allow the chicken to marinate for at least 1–2 hours in the refrigerator.
Heat ghee in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves and green chilies; sauté for 30 seconds until aromatic.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add marinated chicken pieces to the pan and sear on high flame for 5–6 minutes.
Reduce flame to medium and cover the pan, cooking for 10–12 minutes until chicken is tender.
Uncover and increase flame slightly to allow chicken to roast evenly.
Stir occasionally to coat chicken pieces with ghee and spices.
Continue cooking until chicken turns golden and aromatic.
Check seasoning and adjust salt if needed.
Add a little more ghee at the end for enhanced flavor.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Remove from pan and let it rest for 2–3 minutes.
Serve hot as a flavorful starter or main dish.
howToServe: Serve hot with onion rings, lemon wedges, and green chutney.

name: Chicken Dry Fry (Udupi)
ingredients: 750g chicken (cut into small pieces, bone-in preferred)
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken pieces thoroughly.
Marinate chicken with turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, black pepper, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, and salt.
Allow marinated chicken to rest for 1–2 hours.
Heat oil in a wide pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves and green chilies; sauté for 30 seconds until aromatic.
Add finely sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add marinated chicken pieces and sear on high flame for 5 minutes.
Reduce flame to medium and cover the pan.
Cook chicken for 15–20 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Check chicken for tenderness and cook until almost dry.
Increase flame and roast chicken further to get a semi-crispy texture.
Adjust salt and spice levels as needed.
Sprinkle garam masala over the chicken and mix well.
Drizzle a little more oil if required to enhance flavor.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Remove from pan and let it rest for 2–3 minutes.
Serve hot as a dry, spicy Udupi-style starter or side dish.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, sliced onions, and coconut chutney.

name: Mutton Fry (Spicy Masala)
steps: Wash and pat dry mutton pieces thoroughly.
Marinate mutton with turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, black pepper, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, and salt.
Allow marinated mutton to rest for 1–2 hours.
Heat oil in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves and green chilies; sauté for 30 seconds until aromatic.
Add sliced onions and fry until golden brown.
Add marinated mutton pieces and sear on high flame for 5–7 minutes.
Reduce flame to medium and cover the pan.
Cook mutton for 25–30 minutes, stirring occasionally to prevent sticking.
Check mutton for tenderness and continue cooking if required.
Increase flame slightly to reduce excess gravy and get a semi-dry fry consistency.
Sprinkle garam masala over the mutton and mix thoroughly.
Adjust salt and spices to taste.
Add a few drops of lemon juice for tanginess.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Remove from pan and let it rest for 3–5 minutes.
Serve hot as a spicy main dish or dry fry starter.
howToServe: Serve hot with paratha, appam, or steamed rice, garnished with coriander and lemon wedges.

name: Mutton Sukka Fry
ingredients: 3 tbsp coconut oil or regular oil
steps: Wash and pat dry mutton pieces thoroughly.
Marinate mutton with turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, black pepper, ginger-garlic paste, lemon juice, and salt.
Allow the mutton to rest for 1–2 hours for better flavor absorption.
Heat coconut oil in a heavy-bottomed pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves and green chilies; sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add finely sliced onions and fry until golden brown and slightly crisp.
Add marinated mutton pieces and sear on high flame for 5–7 minutes until edges brown.
Reduce flame to medium-low, cover the pan, and cook for 25–30 minutes.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and ensure even cooking.
Add grated coconut and continue frying, mixing well with the mutton.
Cook uncovered to allow excess moisture to evaporate for a dry fry consistency.
Sprinkle garam masala over the mutton and mix thoroughly.
Taste and adjust salt and spice levels if necessary.
Add a few drops of lemon juice to enhance flavor.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves before serving.
Allow the dish to rest for 2–3 minutes before plating to intensify flavors.
Serve hot as a spicy, dry starter or side dish with steamed rice or roti.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, onion slices, and fresh coriander garnish for enhanced aroma and taste.

name: Fish Fry (Plain Masala)
ingredients: 500g fish fillets (seer, kingfish, or pomfret preferred)
steps: Wash and pat dry the fish fillets thoroughly.
Make slits on thick fillets for better marinade absorption.
In a bowl, mix lemon juice, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, black pepper, garam masala, and salt to form a smooth paste.
Coat the fish fillets evenly with the marinade.
Refrigerate for 30–45 minutes to allow flavors to penetrate.
Heat oil or ghee in a non-stick pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves and sauté briefly until fragrant.
Place marinated fish fillets carefully in the pan.
Sear each side for 4–5 minutes until golden brown.
Lower the flame and cook for another 5–7 minutes, ensuring the fish cooks through.
Flip carefully to avoid breaking the fillets.
Baste with oil or ghee intermittently for a rich taste.
Check seasoning and adjust if necessary.
Cook until the outer layer is crisp while the inside remains tender and juicy.
Remove fish from the pan and place on a serving plate.
Garnish with curry leaves and freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Serve immediately for best flavor and texture.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges and a side of steamed rice or roti.

name: Fish Rava Fry
ingredients: 500g fish fillets (kingfish, mackerel, or seer fish)
steps: Wash and pat dry fish fillets thoroughly.
Make shallow slits on thicker fillets for better marinade penetration.
In a bowl, mix ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper, coriander powder, garam masala, lemon juice, and salt.
Coat the fish fillets evenly with the marinade and let rest for 30–45 minutes.
In a separate plate, combine semolina and rice flour.
Dredge each marinated fillet in the rava mixture, pressing lightly to coat evenly.
Heat oil in a frying pan over medium flame.
Place the coated fillets gently in the pan, ensuring not to overcrowd.
Fry on medium heat for 5–6 minutes on one side until golden and crisp.
Carefully flip the fillets to cook the other side for another 5–6 minutes.
Adjust flame to avoid burning the rava coating.
Ensure fish is cooked through but remains juicy inside.
Remove fillets onto a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil.
Garnish with freshly chopped coriander leaves.
Serve hot immediately to retain crispiness.
Optionally, squeeze fresh lemon juice on top before serving for extra flavor.
howToServe: Serve hot with sliced onions, lemon wedges, and coconut chutney or tomato sauce.

name: Fish Masala Fry
ingredients: 500g fish fillets (kingfish, seer fish, or mackerel)
steps: Clean and pat dry the fish fillets.
Make shallow cuts on thick pieces to help absorb the marinade.
In a bowl, mix ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, black pepper powder, garam masala, lemon juice, and salt.
Coat the fish fillets thoroughly with the spice mixture.
Let the fish marinate for 30–60 minutes in the refrigerator.
Spread rice flour on a plate for coating the marinated fish.
Dredge each fish fillet in rice flour, shaking off excess.
Heat oil in a pan on medium flame.
Add curry leaves to the oil for aroma, if using.
Place the fillets carefully in the hot oil.
Fry the fish on medium heat for 5–6 minutes per side until crisp and golden brown.
Avoid high heat to prevent burning the masala coating.
Flip gently to cook the other side evenly.
Check for doneness; the fish should be cooked but juicy inside.
Remove fillets onto a paper towel to drain excess oil.
Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
Serve immediately to maintain crispiness.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, onion rings, and coconut or tomato chutney.

name: Anjal (Seer Fish) Fry
ingredients: 1/4 cup rice flour or semolina for coating
steps: Clean and pat dry the Anjal fish slices.
Make shallow slits on thick slices for better flavor absorption.
Mix ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper powder, coriander powder, lemon juice, and salt in a bowl.
Coat the fish slices with this marinade evenly.
Let it marinate for 30–60 minutes in the refrigerator.
Place rice flour or semolina in a plate for coating the fish.
Dredge the marinated fish slices in flour or semolina, shaking off excess.
Heat oil in a frying pan over medium heat.
Add curry leaves to the hot oil for aroma, if desired.
Place fish slices gently in the pan.
Fry on medium flame for 4–5 minutes on one side until golden brown.
Flip carefully to fry the other side evenly.
Ensure the fish is cooked thoroughly but remains moist inside.
Remove the fried fish onto paper towels to drain excess oil.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve immediately for best taste and crispiness.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, coconut chutney, or a spicy dip.

name: Kane (Lady Fish) Fry
ingredients: 1/4 cup rice flour or semolina for coating
steps: Clean and pat dry the Kane fish slices.
Make shallow slits on thick slices for better marinade absorption.
In a bowl, combine ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper powder, coriander powder, lemon juice, and salt.
Coat the fish slices evenly with the marinade.
Marinate for at least 30–60 minutes in the refrigerator.
Spread rice flour or semolina on a plate for coating.
Dredge the marinated fish slices in flour or semolina, shaking off excess.
Heat oil in a frying pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves to the hot oil for flavor, if desired.
Gently place fish slices into the pan.
Fry for 4–5 minutes on one side until golden and crisp.
Flip carefully and fry the other side evenly.
Ensure the fish is cooked inside but remains moist.
Remove onto paper towels to drain excess oil.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and a squeeze of lemon.
Serve immediately while hot and crispy.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges, coconut chutney, or a tangy dip.

name: Bangude (Mackerel) Fry
ingredients: 1/4 cup rice flour or semolina for coating
steps: Clean and pat dry the Bangude fish slices.
Make shallow slits on thick slices for better marinade absorption.
In a bowl, mix ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper powder, coriander powder, lemon juice, and salt.
Coat fish slices evenly with the marinade.
Refrigerate and marinate for 30–60 minutes.
Spread rice flour or semolina on a plate.
Dredge the marinated fish slices lightly in flour or semolina.
Heat oil in a frying pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves to the oil for aroma if desired.
Place fish slices gently into the hot oil.
Fry for 4–5 minutes on one side until golden and crisp.
Flip carefully and fry the other side until evenly cooked.
Ensure the fish is cooked but remains juicy inside.
Remove onto paper towels to drain excess oil.
Garnish with coriander leaves and a few lemon wedges.
Serve immediately while hot and crispy.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, lemon wedges, or a tangy dip.

name: Boothai (Sardine) Fry
ingredients: 500g boothai (sardine) fish, cleaned and cut into slices
1/4 cup rice flour or semolina for coating
steps: Clean and pat dry sardine slices.
Make shallow slits on thick pieces for better marinade absorption.
In a bowl, mix ginger-garlic paste, turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper powder, coriander powder, lemon juice, and salt.
Coat sardine slices evenly with the marinade.
Refrigerate and marinate for 30–60 minutes.
Spread rice flour or semolina on a plate.
Dredge the marinated sardine slices lightly in flour or semolina.
Heat oil in a frying pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves to the oil for aroma if desired.
Place fish slices gently into hot oil.
Fry for 3–4 minutes on one side until golden and crisp.
Flip carefully and fry the other side until cooked evenly.
Ensure fish is crisp outside but juicy inside.
Remove onto paper towels to drain excess oil.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and lemon wedges.
Serve immediately while hot.
howToServe: Serve hot with coconut chutney, tomato-onion salad, or lemon wedges.

name: Prawn Garlic Fry
steps: Clean and pat dry the prawns thoroughly.
Heat oil in a pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves, garlic, sliced onion, and green chilies; sauté until garlic turns golden brown and fragrant.
Sprinkle turmeric, red chili powder, black pepper, and salt; mix well.
Add prawns and toss to coat evenly with the garlic and spices.
Cook for 5–7 minutes until prawns turn pink and firm.
Stir occasionally to prevent sticking and ensure even cooking.
Taste and adjust salt or spice if needed.
Cook until the masala is dry and prawns are coated well.
Remove from heat and garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve immediately as a dry appetizer or with steamed rice.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges and sliced onions for added flavor.

name: Prawn Pepper Fry
steps: Clean and pat dry prawns thoroughly.
Heat oil in a pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves, sliced onion, and green chilies; sauté until onions are golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and sauté for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
Sprinkle turmeric, red chili powder, and salt; mix well.
Add prawns and stir to coat them evenly with the spices.
Cook on medium flame for 5–7 minutes until prawns turn pink and firm.
Add freshly ground black pepper and garam masala; mix well.
Continue cooking for another 2–3 minutes to allow spices to coat prawns fully.
Adjust seasoning as needed.
Remove from flame once prawns are cooked and masala is dry.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with steamed rice or as an appetizer with lemon wedges and sliced onions.

name: Crab Fry (masala coating)
steps: Clean and crack the crab pieces.
Heat oil in a pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves, sliced onion, and green chilies; sauté until onions turn golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
Sprinkle turmeric, red chili, coriander powder, and salt; mix well.
Add crab pieces and coat with the masala mixture.
Cover and cook on medium flame for 10–12 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Add garam masala and black pepper powder; toss well.
Increase flame and stir-fry until crab is dry and masala sticks to the shells.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or spice if needed.
Remove from pan once shells turn bright red and the masala is absorbed.
Garnish with lemon wedges and fresh coriander leaves.
Serve immediately as a spicy starter or side dish.
howToServe: Serve hot with lemon wedges and onion rings.

name: Chicken Kori Fry (spicy coastal style)
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken pieces.
Heat oil in a pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves, sliced onion, and green chilies; sauté until onions turn golden.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for 1–2 minutes until aromatic.
Sprinkle turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, and salt; mix well.
Add chicken pieces and coat them with the masala.
Cover and cook on medium flame for 15–20 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Once chicken is tender, increase flame and fry until oil separates from masala.
Add black pepper powder and garam masala; toss well.
Check seasoning and adjust if needed.
Continue frying for 3–5 minutes until chicken is dry and coated with spices.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve immediately.
howToServe: Serve hot with sliced onions, lemon wedges, and rice or roti.

name: Chicken Ajadina Fry (dry masala fry)
steps: Wash and pat dry chicken pieces.
Heat oil in a pan over medium flame.
Add curry leaves, sliced onions, and green chilies; sauté until onions turn golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste and fry for 1–2 minutes until fragrant.
Sprinkle turmeric, red chili powder, coriander powder, fennel seeds, and salt; mix well.
Add chicken pieces and coat them thoroughly with the masala.
Cook on medium flame, stirring occasionally, until chicken is tender (15–20 minutes).
Increase flame and fry until chicken is dry and masala sticks well to the pieces.
Add black pepper powder and garam masala; toss evenly.
Check seasoning and adjust if required.
Continue frying for another 3–5 minutes for a crisp exterior.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves.
Serve hot immediately with lemon wedges or as an accompaniment to rice.
howToServe: Serve hot with sliced onions, lemon wedges, and steamed rice or roti.
